That doesn't necessarily mean he is for sure leaving for L.A., but it does mean it's at least something he is considering.\n\nAll indications are that the Lakers will be willing to pay whatever it takes to bring in Hurley, so now the decision is up to him. He has built up a phenomenal program with the Huskies but with the current landscape of the NCAA and NIL and the transfer portal, now may be a better time than ever to make the jump to the NBA and compete for championships with LeBron James, Anthony Davis and whoever else the Lakers add to their roster.\n\nIf Hurley were to leave, then in addition to giving him a lucrative, long-term contract, the Lakers would also need to pay his $1.875 buyout from UConn.\n\nLeBron James has made it clear that he is not involved in the Lakers' coaching search, but a social media post has now surfaced from earlier this year when he had high praise for Dan Hurley.\n\nIt's unclear if James would want to play for Hurley at this stage of his career, but the latter certainly has the King's respect from an Xs {"uri": "2024-06-380835016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:13:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:13:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:57:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/nba-rumors-lakers-targeting-dan-hurley-jj-redick-stunning-twist", "title": "NBA rumors: Lakers targeting Dan Hurley over JJ Redick in stunning twist", "body": "The Lakers seemed set to be hiring JJ Redick as their next head coach, but they have now shockingly turned their attention towards Dan Hurley.\n\nThe Los Angeles Lakers have been looking long and hard for their next head coach after they fired Darvin Ham earlier this offseason. Recent reports seemed to indicate that JJ Redick was on his way to becoming Ham's replacement, but in a shocking turn of events, it now appears that LA is gunning hard for UConn men's basketball coach Dan Hurley, and they are rumored to be preparing a massive contract offer for him in an effort to lure him away from the Huskies.\n\nHurley is fresh off leading UConn to two straight NCAA Championships, and while he obviously had some interest from NBA teams looking to bring him to the pros, he generally didn't seem to be in a rush to leave the Huskies. That hasn't stopped the Lakers, though, and they are looking to pull out all the stops to bring Hurley out west.\n\nWhile the Hurley news itself is wildly surprising, there's an added element of shock given how it seemed like Redick was closing in on the job. Now, he could be kicked to the curb in favor of Hurley, despite his strong friendship with LeBron James. There's still a lot of work that needs to be done to get this deal across the finish line, but Redick could find himself on the outside looking in when it comes to LA's head coaching search now.\n\nLakers willing to do whatever it takes to land Dan Hurley\n\nUConn's basketball has been known more for their women's team than their men's team in recent years, but since taking over as the team's head coach back in 2018, Hurley has changed that narrative. The Huskies men's team has become a powerhouse, as they have coasted to victory in the past two March Madness tournaments to establish themselves as the top team in the nation.\n\nIt's not hard to see why the Lakers have such an interest in Hurley. While winning college and winning in the pros are two different things, Hurley has turned the Huskies into a perennial winner. After a pair of rocky seasons with Ham at the helm, Los Angeles wants to find a way to maximize their chances of winning before James eventually calls it a career.\n\nOf course, the first order of business LA has this offseason, regardless of whether or not they hire Hurley, is finding a way to keep James in town. LeBron has a player option in his deal, and should he opt out, he could test the open market in search of a new home. That's obviously not what the Lakers want to happen, so they have to find a way to persuade James to finish his career in Los Angeles.\n\nHiring Hurley, who is one of the top head coaches in the game of basketball right now, would be a great way to prove to James that they are intent on building a winner around him for the final years of his career. There's still a lot of work to be done before any potential deal comes to fruition, but there's clearly some momentum trending in this direction, and the Lakers could very well end up pulling off this Woj later reported on SportsCenter that Hurley has \"shown the willingness\" to listen to the Lakers after the franchise has already had \"preliminary contact\" with Hurley.\n\nAccording to the NBA insider, Hurley has been at the forefront of the Lakers' coaching search all along, even with the organization already interviewing other candidates.\n\nHurley is undoubtedly the most sought-after coach in all of basketball having won back-to-back titles with the Huskies while posting a record of 68-11 over the last two seasons. The only 'mark' on Hurley's resume is that he does not have any coaching experience in the NBA.\n\nThe interesting dynamic in this Hurley to Los Angeles hypothetical is how his coaching style would translate to the professional level. The 51-year-old is among the most-intense coaches in college basketball and brings a more old-school approach to the bench that has escaped much of the sport, especially in the NBA, over recent years.\n\nOutside of making more money, living in Los Angeles, and coaching LeBron James, the Lakers job has to be intriguing to Hurley given that there is no NIL or transfer portal to worry about in the NBA. Instead of working 365 days a year, Hurley would be working fewer days while adding to his bank account.\n\nHe has certainly navigated the choppy NIL waters at the college level extremely well, and even explained that he's coached his UConn players \"harder\" since they began getting paid, but not having to deal with that aspect of the sport while focusing on coaching may be a path Hurley is Success did not take long to find.\n\nIn his fifth season as head coach, Hurley led a 4-seed Huskies team all the way to the national championship. Despite the pressure of repeating in 2023-24, UConn did just that, looking rather dominant in every game it played along the way to its second straight national championship.\n\nIn six seasons with the Huskies, Hurley has a record of 141-58. He is 292-163 overall in his college coaching career. To go along with that record, Hurley has reached the NCAA Tournament a grand total of six times, holding a 14-4 record in it. Hurley was the national Coach of the Year in 2024, the Big East Coach of the Year in 2024 and the A-10 Coach of the Year in 2018.\n\nIf the money and contract is right, Hurley would be crazy to not take the Lakers' gig, according to UConn women's coach Geno Auriemma.\n\n\"If Danny were to leave, and somebody said to me, you know, he just took this NBA job,\" Auriemma said on the Dan Patrick Show. \"I won't name any particular city, I would say, you know, you're set up for failure. He is well-known for his mastery of X's and O's and fiery competitive attitude, both of which caught Lakers superstar LeBron James' attention after UConn's title run.\n\nIronically enough, James made his lone public comment praising Hurley in a response to the championship coach's appearance on ... The tweet now has over one million views.\n\nHurley has been an NCAA Division-I head coach for 14 years. {"uri": "8164575852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:33:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:33:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:32:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://uproxx.com/dimemag/lakers-dan-hurley-uconnn-offer-next-coach-jj-redick/", "title": "The Lakers Will Make A 'Massive Offer' For UConn Coach Dan Hurley", "body": "For several days, all indications have pointed to ESPN analyst JJ Redick as the overwhelming favorite to become the next head coach of the Los Angeles Lakers. Though the college-to-pro jump has been less in vogue in recent years, Hurley is highly respected and, as ESPN writes, \"LeBron James has been impressed with Hurley's sophisticated offensive actions.\"\n\nIt remains to be seen as to whether Hurley will sign on the dotted line. {"uri": "2024-06-380986978", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:20:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:20:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:11:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://clutchpoints.com/uconn-basketball-news-dan-hurley-draws-jim-harbaugh-comparisons-lakers-rumor", "title": "UConn basketball's Dan Hurley draws Jim Harbaugh comparisons after Lakers rumor", "body": "Dan Hurley might be leaving for LA right after winning a national title.\n\nThe Los Angeles Lakers head coaching search took a major turn on Thursday as ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported that the Lakers are prepared to offer UConn basketball head coach Dan Hurley a huge contract offer. Hurley has won back-to-back national championships with the Huskies and he made it very clear when the offseason started that he wanted to stay at UConn. Now, it's looking like there is a chance that he goes in a different direction.\n\n\"The Los Angeles Lakers are targeting UConn men's basketball coach Dan Hurley as the franchise's next coach and are preparing a massive, long-term contract offer to bring the back-to-back NCAA national champion to the NBA, sources told ESPN,\" The report from Adrian Wojnarowski said. \"The Lakers have had preliminary contact with Hurley and the sides are planning to escalate discussions in the coming days, sources told ESPN. Hurley has been at the forefront of the Lakers' search from the beginning of the process, even while the organization has done its due diligence interviewing several other candidates, sources said.\"\n\nThis is a major twist in the head coaching search because on Wednesday, The Athletic's Shams Charania reported that the Lakers are 'zeroing in on' JJ Redick to become the next head coach in Los Angeles. Redick's name is the one that has been talked about the most during this search, but now that is starting to change.\n\n\"The Los Angeles Lakers are zeroing in on JJ Redick as the front-runner to be the franchise's next head coach, league and media industry sources told The Athletic,\" The report from Shams Charania said.\n\nThis move by Dan Hurley would look familiar\n\nDan Hurley has won the last two national championships with UConn basketball, and now he might be leaving the school to go to the NBA. Sounds familiar, right? That's because former Michigan football head coach Jim Harbaugh just left the Wolverines right after the winning the national championship, and he is now coaching a professional team in Los Angeles. Harbaugh is the head coach of the Los Angeles Chargers, and Hurley could be the coach of the Lakers soon.\n\nA lot of people are making this comparison, and a lot of people think that it says a lot about the current state of college sports.\n\n\"Jim Harbaugh and Danny Hurley -- fresh off national titles -- jetting to the pros within months of each other is a sad commentary on the state of college athletics,\" Paul Hembekides said in a tweet.\n\nCollege sports has already lost two great coaches this offseason, and Hurley could be the third.\n\n\"Losing Saban, Harbaugh and Hurley from college sports so far in 2024 is a real bummer,\" Brandon Zimmerman said in a tweet. \"I was very interested to watch Hurley go for the first 3-peat since John Wooden next season.\"\n\nOther people don't think that this comparison isn't fair as Jim Harbaugh had flirted with the NFL a ton before this season and clearly wanted to go back to try to get a Super Bowl. Also, this is a pretty attractive offer for Hurley.\n\n\"Harbaugh, an NFL guy at his core, did what he set out to do at Michigan and it's not like Hurley is jumping for the Charlotte Hornets job or something,\" Derek Schulz said in a tweet. \"Don't think either decision is an indictment on college sports whatsoever.\"\n\nNo matter what happens, this is a twist that not a lot of people saw coming. It seemed like Dan Hurley was firmly set on staying with the UConn basketball team for a long time, but now it's looking like he could be heading to Los Angeles. Los Angeles has reportedly been in contact with Hurley already, with discussions expected to \"escalate\" in the next few days as he's been at the \"forefront\" of the team's head-coach search from the start.\n\nHurley, 51, has helped UConn return to prominence in college basketball in recent years, leading the Huskies to back-to-back championships over the last two seasons. He's gone 141-58 at UConn and 292-163 in his career as a college head coach with previous stops at Wagner and Rhode Island.\n\nWhile Hurley has never coached in the NBA before, Lakers owner Jeanie Buss and general manager Rob Pelinka are \"eager\" to discuss their vision for what the head coach can do at the professional level, according to ESPN. Hurley has also \"expressed\" to Los Angeles an interest in coaching the franchise as he has ambitions to coach in the NBA, ESPN added in its report.\n\nThursday's news is a bit of a curveball compared to what's been reported over the last few weeks. The Lakers were zeroing in on J.J. Redick to become their next coach, The Athletic reported Tuesday. As there was some belief that Redick would replace Darvin Ham, the other candidates who had reportedly interviewed for the job were NBA assistant coaches and former head coaches (Boston Celtics assistant Sam Cassell and former Charlotte Hornets head coach James Borrego being the most notable).\n\nLakers star LeBron James' connection to Redick also played a role in the belief that the former player turned broadcaster was the favorite to get the job. The two began hosting a podcast together, \"Mind the Game,\" in March, discussing hot topics in basketball and the nuances of the sport.\n\nShortly after Thursday's news broke though, a social media post of James praising Hurley resurfaced, indicating that he's a fan of the UConn coach.\n\n\"He's so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff,\" James wrote in a social media post in April about Hurley following UConn's second straight national title. \"Super creative with their O! Love it\"\n\nMeanwhile, Redick said Wednesday that his focus was on the NBA Finals and that he would address his candidacy for the Lakers' job at a later time. {"uri": "8164834967", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:09:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:09:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:08:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://ftw.usatoday.com/2024/06/dan-hurley-lakers-lebron-james-bronny-jj-redick-uconn", "title": "Dan Hurley as coach of the Lakers makes more sense for Bronny James than it does for LeBron", "body": "Early on Thursday morning, ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski shocked the NBA world with a report about the Los Angeles Lakers head coaching vacancy.\n\nAccording to Wojnarowski, the Lakers are preparing a \"massive, long-term\" contract that would bring UConn Huskies head coach Dan Hurley from the college ranks to the NBA.\n\nThis is, obviously, a major change of pace from previous reports indicating that former NBA veteran and ESPN commentator JJ Redick was likely going to accept the gig after he completed his on-air duties for the NBA Finals.\n\nAt first blush, this doesn't seem to make a ton of sense for LeBron James. After all, LeBron co-hosts a basketball podcast with Redick and the two have great chemistry together on the show.\n\nTo be clear, that isn't to suggest that LeBron isn't a fan of Hurley or what he has accomplished at UConn. In fact, the NBA's all-time leading scorer posted a reply to a recent podcast appearance featuring Hurley with very high praise.\n\nThe host of that podcast was none other than Redick, who may assumed was previously the frontrunner to take over as head coach of the Lakers before the recent report about Hurley surfaced.\n\nLeBron is clearly impressed by Hurley and after two consecutive collegiate national championships, it is easy to see why.\n\nBut for all of his accolades and accomplishments that he has earned thus far, what he is most celebrated for is his ability to get the most out of young players. Even in ESPN's initial report, Hurley's \"elite player development\" is unsurprisingly one of the first traits mentioned.\n\nThat matters significantly, per Wojnarowski, and could mean a lot to the future of LeBron's son Bronny:\n\n\"Assuming James returns to L.A. in free agency, the possibility of using the 55th pick in this month's NBA draft on USC freshman guard Bronny James makes Hurley an even more intriguing candidate. If that happens, James gets a chance to play with his son and the benefit of Hurley and his staff becoming responsible for Bronny's pro development.\"\n\nWojnarowski continued that thought during an appearance on ESPN's UNSPORTSMANLIKE Radio.\n\nHere is more from Woj:\n\n\"You're gonna have to grow your young players and the idea of Bronny James and the Lakers: They have the 55th pick. Who better potentially than Dan Hurley to be the development coach to lead his growth than the coach who has really dominated the college sport?\"\n\nFor what it is worth, though, Bronny (a former McDonald's All-American) did not receive an offer from Hurley and UConn when he was coming out of high school.\n\nBut of course, it isn't just Bronny (who isn't even on the Lakers roster at this point) that Los Angeles is considering when targeting Hurley.\n\nWojnarowski added:\n\n\"This is a decision and an idea for beyond LeBron James. I think Anthony Davis is at the forefront of this conversation ... He wants to have a voice in this. He wants to be on the same page with this new head coach, whoever it is, and see how that new coach may use him, the actions he can put him in.\"\n\nOverall, the messaging is that this hire is not about a 39-year-old LeBron and more about the rest of the roster.\n\nHere are some thoughts from ESPN's Brian Windhorst:\n\n\"LeBron told the Lakers they need to make a decision on their head coach that's not just about me, it's not just about what's good for me for this year, next year ... It's going to be about what you need to do for your franchise. It's going to be about Anthony Davis. That is what he said ... He wants the Lakers to do what's best for their team long-term. If the Lakers make a hire like this, it's not for LeBron.\"\n\nThere is a lot to unpack here but the reality is that Hurley has most of his experience coaching players like Bronny, who have the potential to improve but aren't where they want to be as basketball players quite yet.\n\nDoes that mean he is incapable of coaching stars like LeBron and Davis?\n\nWe have seen him have tremendous success in the NCAA using NBA-style schemes and systems, so it could potentially translate.\n\nWhen you watch Hurley coach, you can see why his message resonates well with players Bronny's age and may not have that same impact on NBA vets. All things considered, this coach seems to make the most sense for a younger roster where the Lakers are a team loaded with experienced pros.\n\nNBA Finals Game 1 odds and predictions: Luka Doncic on a rested knee could be trouble for Boston Here's how the Celtics and Mavericks stacked up against each other in the 2024 regular season Why Kyrie Irving left the Boston Celtics, explained Here's how Grant Williams could get a championship ring from the Celtics-Mavericks NBA Finals The Lakers are reportedly targeting Dan Hurley as coach and fans were stunned at the turn of events", "source": {"uri": "8164972379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:40:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:40:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:39:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://arizonasports.com/story/3548729/dan-hurley-top-candidate-lakers-coaching-search/", "title": "Report: Dan Hurley top candidate in Lakers coaching search", "body": "UConn head men's basketball coach Dan Hurley, the younger brother of Arizona State's Bobby Hurley, is the primary target for the Los Angeles Lakers in their search for a new head coach, reports ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski.\n\nThe team is preparing a \"massive\" deal to present to Hurley. The Lakers are expected to have deeper discussions \"in the coming days\" to persuade Hurley to leave UConn, where he has won consecutive national championships.\n\nWojnarowski adds Hurley and the Lakers have held preliminary talks, and the UConn coach has been the No. 1 target as the team has met with others, such as former NBA player J.J. Redick and former Charlotte Hornets head coach James Borrego.\n\nLos Angeles fired second-year head coach Darvin Ham after a first-round playoff exit this year.\n\nSince the final buzzer sounded with the Huskies winning the championship in April, Hurley, 51, has been adamant about returning and staying at UConn for the longhaul.\n\nWhile the Huskies lost center Donovan Clingan and guard Stephon Castle, who are likely lottery picks in the draft, Hurley saw Alex Karaban pull out of the draft and then landed Saint Mary's transfer Aidan Mahaney. All-in-all, they are viewed as a top-10 team.\n\nUConn had so far survived keeping Hurley despite overtures from the likes of Kentucky, which was seeking to replace John Calipari after his move to Arkansas.\n\n\"My answer to that (Kentucky interest) was 'no.' I'm the head coach at the best program in the country,\" Hurley told The Dan Patrick Show in April. \"Why would I leave the best program in the country even if another place is really good or great? But your agent wants you to try to deflect.\n\n\"You want to reward your staff, you want to increase the resources in your program. So your agent is kind of telling you: 'Don't say you're interested but don't say no because I've got to deal with the UConn people.'\"\n\nHurley and UConn are currently in extension negotiations that Hurley addressed on Wednesday night.\n\nLike his brother Bobby, Dan Hurley had leaned into the changing ways of college basketball despite complaints -- which have been filtered through his humor -- about the transfer portal and NIL.\n\nBut in the NBA, Hurley would bring immediate credibility because of his offensive sets that play to the pace of the NBA. His UConn team also competed on the defensive end, and the combination of all those things saw UConn's closest deficit during a six-game tournament run end up as a 14-point win over Alabama in the Final Four.\n\nUConn's execution and complexities of their offense drew eyes from NBA perspectives, most notably from Redick and his current podcast partner, Lakers star LeBron James.\n\nLos Angeles has approached their search with an emphasis on building beyond the James era, and Hurley's potential development of players like Austin Reaves and Max Christie is being considered here.\n\nThe question would be whether Hurley's brash, in-your-face style will be subdued while working with older players and NBA stars.\n\nAccording to ESPN Stats & Info, UConn was third in Division I basketball with 25 technical fouls since Hurley arrived there in 2018-19. To paint the picture of his fire, Hurley was shoving his own player while stepping on the court in the final three minutes of the national championship game when his team led by 15 points in April.\n\nHurley, whose father Bob Hurley Sr. is a Hall of Fame High School coach in New Jersey, got his start as an assistant at Rutgers from 1997-2001.\n\nHe coached the next decade at St. Benedict's prep before jumping into college as head coach at Wagner (2010-12) and Rhode Island (2012-18). Bobby Hurley coached as an assistant to Dan at both schools until he took the Buffalo head-coaching job from 2013-15. Bobby Hurley left for the Arizona State job in 2015.\n\nIf Hurley does take the Lakers job, it's not wild to assume the fallout could impact the teams in Arizona, in some fashion.\n\nUConn's talented returning roster would be at risk of dissolving.\n\nArizona State Sun Devil fans could hope Hurley sends some players his brother's way. You could look at Mahaney, who is from Campolindo High School in California, as a dream candidate and floor general for a rebuilt Sun Devil squad.\n\nArizona Wildcat fans are coming from the Jedd Fisch-to-Washington trauma that began with a college coaching legend, Nick Saban, stepping away on the football side. They might hope their head basketball coach Tommy Lloyd, isn't viewed as a candidate to replace Hurley out East. That would be viewed as a longshot since Lloyd is from the Pacific Northwest and doesn't have the postseason resume to wow UConn boosters.\n\nBut some former Arizona coaches might be the new faces of UConn.\n\nCurrent Huskies assistant Luke Murray, the son of Bill Murray, could be viewed as a legitimate in-house replacement option. He was a graduate assistant under Sean Miller at Arizona from 2009-10 and worked with both Hurleys at Wagner in 2010-11.\n\nMiller's name might be floated, too, though he's coming off a 16-18 season, the second year of his second stint at Xavier.", "source": {"uri": "arizonasports.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arizona Sports"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kevin_zimmerman@arizonasports.com", "name": {"uri": "8164533402", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:07:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:07:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:07:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://lebronwire.usatoday.com/2024/06/06/report-lakers-targeting-uconn-champion-dan-hurley-as-head-coach/", "title": "Report: Lakers targeting UConn champion Dan Hurley as head coach", "body": "The Los Angeles Lakers are zeroing in on making a hire to replace Darvin Ham as they look to move forward after a disappointing finish to the 2023-24 season. LA was ousted in five games in the first round by the Denver Nuggets prompting the Ham firing.\n\nAfter talks of the potential replacement being somebody like former sharpshooter JJ Redick or former Orlando Magic and Charlotte Hornets coach James Borrego, the Lakers are zeroing in on UConn champion coach Dan Hurley to be the new head man in LA.\n\nPer ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski:\n\nThe Lakers have had preliminary contact with Hurley and the sides are planning to escalate discussions in the coming days, sources told ESPN. Hurley has been at the forefront of the Lakers' search from the beginning of the process, even while the organization has done its due diligence interviewing several other candidates, sources said.\n\nLakers vice president of basketball operations and general manager Rob Pelinka and governor Jeanie Buss are eager to formally discuss with Hurley their vision of marrying his dominant program -- built upon both his tactical acumen and elite player development -- with the storied Lakers' brand, sources said.\n\nHurley has a 292-163 collegiate coaching record at Wagner, Rhode Island, and UConn. They believe they are still a championship-contending franchise and believe everyone wants to align themselves with them.\n\nSo two-time defending champion UConn coach Dan Hurley? Sure, he's fair game.\n\nPer Adrian Wojnarowski of ESPN, the Lakers are set to make a large and lengthy offer to Hurley to become their next coach. So much for the J.J. Redick rumors.\n\nInterestingly, it's been 20 years to the summer since the Lakers tried to pry away Mike Krzyzewski from Duke University. Krzyzewski said thanks but no thanks, and according to Hoops Wire, Hurley is likely to say the same.\n\n\"No one is really saying as much, but the Lakers job could be thankless,\" one source told the outlet. \"Dan has a good thing going right where he is.\"\n\nCollege coaches tend not to work out in the NBA, though it went OK for former Butler coach Brad Stevens, who went to the Boston Celtics, before eventually becoming their head of basketball operations. But Butler wasn't UConn -- as Hurley could potentially become one of college basketball's all-time coaching legends. The Huskies are two-time defending champs.\n\nYou want to leave that to go deal with an aging LeBron James, an injury-prone Anthony Davis and a Lakers organization that fires its coaches every two years? James has been in Los Angeles since 2018. He's now on his fourth coach.\n\nSo Hurley will probably tell the Lakers to keep their money, and if so, the man could not be blamed.\n\n\"Lakers vice president of basketball operations and general manager Rob Pelinka and governor Jeanie Buss are eager to formally discuss with Hurley their vision of marrying his dominant program -- built upon his tactical acumen and his elite player development -- with the storied Lakers brand,\" Wojnarowski wrote, citing sources.\n\nYawn. {"uri": "8165153287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:52:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:52:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:52:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.courant.com/2024/06/06/dom-amore-uconn-or-lakers-dan-hurley-has-an-excruciating-choice-the-greater-of-two-blessings/", "title": "Dom Amore: UConn or Lakers? Dan Hurley has an excruciating choice, the greater of two blessings", "body": "Chances are good that Dan Hurley is spending Thursday in the space he reserves for deep contemplation, for the news that exploded before rush hour has left the idol of Connecticut with a decision to make, whether to retain the idyllic life he has created here, or reach for even higher ground.\n\n\"I want him to stay because that's good for UConn,\" was Jim Calhoun's succinct way of putting it. \"But he can't lose either way.\"\n\nThe Lakers, Adrian Wojnarowski first reported for ESPN, are preparing to make a \"massive offer\" to hire Hurley, and sources everywhere confirm the interest is real, even if it is a little unusual for them to decide six weeks into their search to go all out for the hottest name in the game. That's what they've decided to do.\n\nReport: Los Angeles Lakers targeting UConn's Dan Hurley with 'massive contract offer'\n\nAnd it would be very unusual for Hurley, after spurning Kentucky right after winning a second straight title, to go through two months of recruiting, counseling players about staying or coming back to UConn, and making public appearances like the two he made this week, to now decide he would consider moving on. Especially when he has said he's \"not ready\" for the NBA and would need to \"mature as a coach\" before making such a move.\n\nBut that is where we are, because who knows what a massive offer is? Could be $100 million for five years, and that might be enough for any coach to get ready in a hurry. UConn can't outbid the Lakers.\n\nWhen one must choose between the lesser of two evil options, that is excruciating. When must choose between the greater of two blessings, between outrageous money at UConn and generational money in Los Angeles, it can be just as hard, but in a different way. To be great, one must be willing to leave their comfort zone, and that means risking happiness. We should all have such a choice, but that doesn't make it a no-brainer, especially for a guy who shifts his brain into overdrive like Dan Hurley.\n\nForgive the rambling course this is about to take, because Hurley is a complicated and all-over-the-map type. But I'll get to the nub here: I am guessing, as I write at noon, he will stay at UConn, with the pot of gold sweetened by this this episode.\n\nI just wouldn't bet the ranch or his chickens on it.\n\nHurley mentioned in 2019, long before he won at UConn, that coaching in the NBA on his mind. I got some heat for writing it, in fact.\n\n\"That would be my goal,\" Hurley said at a Coaches Road Show stop at Dunkin' Park. \"I would love to win a couple of championships, get UConn back on top of the mountain. I think in the long term, you have to have goals. You have to have things you continue to drive and reach for. I want to be a championship-level coach here and someday, down the road, the NBA is something I'd think about.\"\n\nDan Hurley: 'We've spoiled ourselves,' but UConn men are back to the grind\n\nFive years later, UConn is on top of the mountain and Hurley is on top of the world. He signed a new deal worth $31.5 million last June, and garnered close to $7 million this past season in leading the Huskies to the repeat. Kentucky might have doubled that, but Hurley shut them down early and made clear he never wanted to coach at \"any other college.\"\n\n'The only people you should be talking to is UConn because we have no desire to leave here to coach college basketball anywhere else,'\" Hurley said he told his agent.\n\nAs for the NBA, Hurley said that day, following the parade in Hartford, \"Maybe down the road, you hope you can mature enough emotionally to, much later in my career, try to take a shot at the NBA - down the road, way down the road.\"\n\nHurley appeared Tuesday at the Franciscan Sports Banquet and made clear he was all in, and confident on going for a three-peat. On Wednesday, he appeared at the last of the Coaches Road Shows and again re-affirmed it. But talks for a new contract at UConn are not done, and Hurley told reporters afterward things were \"complicated,\" that he's \"not a businessman.\"\n\nI suggested that the commitment of years might be paramount, but Hurley, 51, then said he didn't plan to coach into his 60s, that by then, he might want to finish his career as a high school coach, where he began, at a place like St. Benedict's in Newark. He and his wife, Andrea, are East Coast folks.\n\nSo there is no telling exactly where he is with this process. Maybe, having surrendered leverage by spurning Kentucky, Hurley and his agent are trying to get UConn president Radenka Maric, who has a responsibility to keep the budget under control, to move the needle and close the deal?\n\nWhen moderator Mike Crispino asked the panel, \"if you could be another coach, who would you be?\" Hurley did not say Phil Jackson or Pat Riley, he named Geno Auriemma, who was shaking his head.\n\nAuriemma actually joked with Hurley about the Lakers job, but later said he didn't know what was going on. If Hurley goes to Hollywood before this week is out, there should be an Oscar waiting for him.\n\nWhat we do know, too, is that coaching anywhere in the NBA, a \"players league,\" is very different from college, where coaches are the rock stars. Calhoun passed up a couple of chances because he knew who he was, that coaching a pro team where the top stars run the show might not be the best fit for him. Hurley undoubtedly knows this, too.\n\nDan Hurley commits to UConn's future, starts construction of 2024-25 roster as he hunts 'three-peat'\n\nAnd coaching the Lakers in 2024 may be the most complicated job in NBA history. LeBron James, 39, one of the two or three greatest players ever, is the franchise. He's won titles in Cleveland, Miami and LA, but his relationships with coaches have created short shelf lives. Now, his son, Bronny, is in the NBA Draft, but not considered a sure-fire prospect. It's assumed that LeBron wants his son on the Lakers.\n\nJames had glowing things to say about UConn's sophisticated offense during the Final Four, and the idea of having Hurley on board to develop his son might be appealing, and I'm not criticizing any of this here.\n\nBut this will be a delicate task, will take political skill and probably a lot of compromise. Are these are conditions for Dan Hurley, a guy who often derides \"helicopter parents,\" to thrive?\n\nOther side of the coin? James won't be playing much longer, and if Hurley can win enough to stay in the job and outlast him, he could eventually have a free hand. And if Hurley has guaranteed, generational money and it doesn't work out in the NBA, he could have his pick of college jobs, like Rick Pitino and John Calipari once did.\n\nSo here we find Dan Hurley on the top of the basketball world, if not the world at-large, deciding whether to stay put and not mess with happy, or shoot for the moon and fall among the stars if he fails. And who is to say, if things go south at UConn when and if a revenue sharing system is implemented, that an NBA opportunity will knock again?\n\nIt's quite a choice, potentially life-changing for the next several generations of Hurleys. My guess, and UConn's hope, is he stays, but we're not the ones with $100 million or so dangling before our eyes. {"uri": "8164654524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:21:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:21:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:19:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/nba/news/lakers-targeting-dan-hurley-uconn-coach-edge-over-jj-redick/245adde0eebb57b97f907f26", "title": "Why Lakers are targeting Dan Hurley: UConn coach's track record gives him edge over JJ Redick", "body": "Give the Lakers credit for aiming big. They are targeting UConn's Dan Hurley as their next head coach per ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski, preparing a massive long-term contract offer for the back-to-back NCAA national champion.\n\nAll signs have pointed to the job being essentially JJ Redick's, so Thursday's early morning news came as a surprise. But it makes sense given Hurley's impeccable coaching resume.\n\nThat interest had been brewing all along, according to Wojnarowski. Hurley had \"been at the forefront of the Lakers' search from the beginning of the process\" due to the Lakers' desire to combine \"his tactical acumen and elite player development -- with the storied Lakers' brand.\"\n\nHere's why Hurley is such an intriguing option for the Lakers.\n\nMORE: Why UConn's Dan Hurley is Sporting News' College Basketball Coach of the Year\n\nThere are few that would be more qualified for this job than Hurley. He's the first men's college coach to win back-to-back national championships since Billy Donovan did it with Florida in 2007. Hurley's 141-58 career record in college is impressive on its face, as is his NCAA tournament record of 12 consecutive double-digit wins.\n\nUConn dominated this past season, going 37-3 and rolling through the NCAA tournament. That came in large part due to Hurley's strategies. No other coach incorporates as much movement into their offenses. His sets are complicated and more precise than a Swiss watch, leading to great shots for his team.\n\nThat play style has caught the eye of LeBron, who \"has been impressed with Hurley's sophisticated offensive actions,\" according to Wojnarowski.\n\nHurley has also developed his players well. Donovan Clingan and Stephon Castle are widely considered to be lottery picks in this upcoming draft. That could be another benefit for LeBron if the team decides to take Bronny with their no. 55 pick in the draft.\n\nHurley has coaching in his blood. His father was a legendary high school coach in New Jersey, winning 26 state championships. His brother was a two-time national champion with Duke and coaches at Arizona State. He was born for this job.\n\nMORE: Get to know famous Hurley coaching brothers\n\nThere are some potential issues that Hurley could encounter if he does decide to accept the Lakers' offer.\n\nFirst among them is building a relationship with LeBron James. He's not an easy star to coach. Being a great tactician is not enough -- he once tried to get Eric Spoelstra fired. Hurley with be the 10th coach of James' career.\n\nHurley's personality will also be an interesting litmus test on what does and doesn't work in the NBA. It has increasingly become a players' league, far different from the college ranks where coaches have more authority. Will that pose a challenge for Hurley, who has never been afraid of expressing his both positive and negative emotions?\n\n\"I'm a crier,\" Hurley recently told FOX Sports. \"I laugh, I yell and I cry. Jim Valvano said that's a full day.\n\nRedick was an attractive option for much different reasons. Knowing how to pace players throughout a much more grueling season is one of the biggest and least appreciated aspects of the job. Other college coaches have failed in that regard, most recently evidenced by John Beilein's short and disastrous tenure with the Cavs.\n\nRedick's 15 years of NBA experience would have given him a huge advantage. His already built-in relationship with James was another checkmark for him.\n\nHurley is the more proven tactician and winner. He has a history of player development that completely outclasses Redick's. You don't know what will happen when you sit in that front seat, which the Lakers saw first-hand with long-time assistant Darvin Ham. Hurley is a much lower risk for the team.\n\nThe next big question is if Hurley will even want the job. He has a great setup at UConn after signing a six year, $31.5 million extension last summer.\n\nThe interest in Hurley is coming at the perfect time for him. Coaching salaries are growing massively ever since the Pistons broke the bank with a six year, $78.5 million deal. Hurley could more than double his salary with a move to the NBA.\n\nMORE: Who are the highest-paid coaches in the NBA?\n\nHurley is going to earn that money, because the Lakers job might be one of the toughest in the league. He will be under intense scrutiny, both internally and externally. This is the same team that had six sources throwing Ham under the bus midway through the year and fired Frank Vogel only two years after winning a championship.\n\nHurley's past experience has shown that he's up to that challenge. It will be fascinating to see how he does.", "source": {"uri": "sportingnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sporting News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8164686736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:39:20", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:39:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:38:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.nbcwashington.com/news/sports/nba/lakers-dan-hurley-uconn-head-coach-target-report/3634514/", "title": "Lakers targeting UConn's Dan Hurley to become next head coach: Report", "body": "Hurley has led the Huskies to back-to-back national championships at the college level\n\nThe Los Angeles Lakers reportedly want to make a back-to-back national champion their next head coach.\n\nESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported Thursday morning that the NBA franchise is preparing a \"massive, long-term\" contract offer for UConn's Dan Hurley.\n\nThe Lakers have had preliminary talks with Hurley and the two sides are planning to have larger conversations in the coming days, Wojnarowski reported.\n\nHurley became the Huskies' head coach in 2018 and has brought the program to the mountaintop in his six-year tenure. The team has made four straight NCAA Tournament appearances and won the 2023 and 2024 national titles with dominant March Madness runs. With a title game win over Purdue in April, UConn became the first team to successfully defend a national title since the Florida Gators in 2006 and 2007.\n\nBefore taking the helm at UConn, Hurley {"uri": "8165164143", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "18:03:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T18:03:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T18:01:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.si.com/nba/lakers/news/lakers-news-11-time-champion-coach-endorses-dan-hurley-joining-la-ml0802", "title": "Lakers News: 11-Time Champion Coach Endorses Dan Hurley Joining LA", "body": "The rumors that the Los Angeles Lakers are now pursuing UConn Huskies head coach Dan Hurley have changed everything for the team. While on the Dan Patrick Show, Auriemma said he was with Hurley recently and had some interesting thoughts on his potential move.\n\n\"I think you could win a lot of championships with the Lakers, more so than a guy who's never coached.\"\n\nHurley is coming off winning two NCAA Championships with the Huskies, giving him some major credibility on the sidelines. If he is hired, the Lakers would be getting one of the most sought-after coaches on the market.\n\nLos Angeles has been looking for a new head coach who can build with the team in the present and in the future. Hurley could present both those things for the Lakers if given the job but he could always stay at UConn.\n\nThe pressure of winning in Los Angeles could see him stay in college, opening the door for Redick to remain the frontrunner. Whatever happens, the Lakers seem to be getting closer to making a decision.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports Illustrated"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UConn_Huskies", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "UConn Huskies"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geno_Auriemma", "type": "person", "score": 4, "https://images2.minutemediacdn.com/image/upload/c_crop,w_2545,h_1431,x_0,y_0/c_fill,w_1440,ar_16:9,f_auto,q_auto,g_auto/images/voltaxMediaLibrary/mmsport/all_lakers/01hzq306yh5k2ssbpbgv.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9629925", "eventUri": "eng-9629925", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": 0.2862745098039217, "wgt": 203, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-06-381052002", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:19:31", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:19:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:45:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.aol.com/coaching-lakers-hard-job-pass-144536693.html", "title": "Coaching the Lakers is a hard job to pass up, except maybe Dan Hurley should", "body": "Coaching the Lakers is a hard job to pass up, except maybe Dan Hurley should\n\nJeff Eisenberg\n\nJune 6, 2024 at 5:00 PM\n\nEarlier this week, during an appearance on The Mike Francesa Podcast, UConn's Dan Hurley left open the possibility of one day leaving for the NBA.\n\nThe coach of college basketball's two-time reigning national champs said that UConn fits him perfectly but that he does aspire to test himself at the highest level \"if the right NBA situation were to come along.\"\n\nWhen Francesa expressed surprise, Hurley elaborated on what the \"right situation\" meant to him. He said it had to be a job \"where an organization wants a tone setter to come in and instill a culture. You know, young players and an organization that wants to pursue championships.\"\n\nThose comments took on newfound meaning early Thursday when ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski dropped a bombshell story with the potential significant implications at both the NBA and college level. The Los Angeles Lakers are targeting Hurley as the franchise's next head coach and are preparing a massive, long-term contract offer, Wojnarowski reported.\n\nIt doesn't take a basketball savant to see why Hurley would be intrigued by the opportunity to coach the Lakers. This is maybe the premier job in basketball. It's a chance to guide a franchise that has captured 17 NBA championships, that has landed high-profile free agent after high-profile free agent and that has never hesitated to pay big-name coaches top dollar.\n\nPhil Jackson earned an annual salary of $12 million near the end of his Lakers tenure that ended 13 years ago. Would it surprise anyone if the Lakers' offer to Hurley surpassed that?\n\nIt also helps that Hurley appears to have the approval of the most powerful man in the Lakers organization. In April, responding to an interview that JJ Redick did with Hurley for his podcast, LeBron James wrote on X: \"He's so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff. Super creative with their O! Love it.\"\n\nThen there's the matter of how much more taxing and exhausting it is to be a college basketball coach today than it was even five years ago. Between the transfer portal and players gaining the potential to receive NIL money, recruiting is more intense and more round-the-clock. This past March, coaches whose teams were in the NCAA tournament were simultaneously raising NIL money, scouting and pursuing transfers and re-recruiting their own players.\n\nHurley himself joked about that on the eve of UConn's national title game showdown against Purdue two months ago. Asked about his biggest motivation during the NCAA tournament, a smiling Hurley quipped, \"I just don't want to deal with the portal s -- . That's why we're trying so hard to win right now.\"\n\n\"I'm seeing what other people are doing, and it's chaos,\" he added. \"I can hide behind, 'Hey, my season's still going on.'\"\n\nThose are all good reasons for Hurley to be tempted by the Lakers job -- but not necessarily for him to take it. He'd be risking a lot going to the Lakers and giving up even more if he leaves a UConn program that he himself has described as a perfect fit.\n\nHistory is littered with successful college basketball coaches who took a shot at leaping to the NBA but failed spectacularly.\n\nIn 1996, the New Jersey Nets hired John Calipari away from UMass on the heels of a Final Four run. The young, brash Calipari lasted only two-plus seasons with the Nets after rubbing veteran players and the New York media the wrong way on more than one occasion.\n\nIn 1997, the Boston Celtics plucked Rick Pitino from Kentucky after he won the 1996 national title and fell one win short of going back-to-back the following year. The result was a 102-146 record and the infamous \"Larry Bird is not walking through that door\" rant.\n\nJerry Tarkanian, Tim Floyd, Fred Hoiberg and Mike Montgomery had similar results. John Beilein somehow fared even worse. Only Billy Donovan and Brad Stevens achieved sustained success at the NBA level -- and even Donovan hasn't won a playoff series since his debut season in Oklahoma City nearly a decade ago.\n\nThe 51-year-old Hurley undeniably has the coaching acumen to thrive in the NBA and the authenticity and fiery demeanor to hold players accountable, but there's also no denying that he's quirky and that his temper burns hot. This is a guy whose practices are legendarily grueling; who searches for the slightest perceived slight to use as motivation; who rants and raves at referees after every close call.\n\nOn the sideline at UConn practices last fall were a set of cardboard posters representing every trophy that the Huskies could win during the upcoming season. Those posters took a beating from Hurley kicking them down or firing projectiles at them whenever he felt his team didn't practice up to its capabilities.\n\nHurley's hand-picked UConn players fed off his nonstop intensity. Would NBA veterans feel the same over the course of an 82-game schedule?\n\nThe Lakers' track record of burning through seven coaches in 13 years is also a red flag that Hurley shouldn't ignore. Frank Vogel lasted two seasons after winning a championship. Darvin Ham was ousted the year after reaching the Western Conference finals. Who's to say that Hurley wouldn't be scapegoated the first time things go awry?\n\nAt UConn, Hurley has the job security that comes with engineering the greatest two-year run in modern men's college basketball history.\n\nIn 2023, a UConn team led by Jordan Hawkins, Andre Jackson and Adama Sanogo trounced its six NCAA tournament opponents by 20 points per game. Five of that team's top eight players moved on, yet last season's Huskies proved to be even more unbeatable, winning six NCAA tournament games by a record-setting 23.3 points apiece.\n\nThe college game may be tough on coaches these days, but Hurley has thrived better than anyone else amid the chaos. He has found a formula that works for him, sometimes passing on the most talented prospects in favor of team-first freshmen and transfers who prioritize winning and who aren't afraid to be coached hard.\n\nThanks to Hurley, UConn now has a chance to become the first program to three-peat since the heyday of John Wooden's UCLA dynasty in the 1970s. The Huskies are a fixture in way-too-early preseason top fives thanks to the return of standout forward Alex Karaban and the arrival of a bevy of accomplished newcomers.\n\nWhen speaking with Francesa earlier this week, Hurley acknowledged that leaving the northeast in general and UConn in particular would be hard for him. He said he hopes to stay \"as long as we're able to find these old-school folks to bring into our program and then we just blend it with modern basketball.\"\n\n\"If we keep doing it like this,\" added Hurley, \"I'll stay here and the NBA will never be a thing.\"\n\nMaybe Hurley should take his own advice. Maybe he should leverage the Lakers' interest into a big raise and then stay where he is beloved.\n\nCoaching the Lakers is a job you can't pass up, except maybe Dan Hurley should.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8164995574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:56:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:56:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:55:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/dan-hurley-has-proven-to-be-a-special-coach-but-would-his-fit-with-the-lakers-make-sense-155351562.html", "title": "Dan Hurley has proven to be a special coach, but would his fit with the Lakers make sense?", "body": "The discussion of the next head coach for the Los Angeles Lakers hit a fervor with reports swirling earlier this week that the Lakers were zeroing in on current ESPN basketball analyst JJ Reddick as their next head coach. Thursday morning, ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported the Lakers are preparing a lucrative, long-term offer for UConn head coach Dan Hurley, and Hurley is now willing to meet with the team.\n\n\"He is the target of their search,\" Wojnarowski said. \"He's been the target for the Lakers search since the beginning. Both sides have had preliminary contact and those conversations are expected to escalate in the coming days.\"\n\nHurley led the UConn Huskies to back-to-back titles after defeating Purdue in the championship game this year, the first repeat since the Florida Gators in 2006-07 and 2007-08. He and his staff have completely revived the program and have now made it a top destination for not only five-star high school recruits but top transfers in the portal. In six seasons at UConn, Hurley is 141-58.\n\n\"We practice 11 months out of the year, and Coach Hurley pushed us to our max every single day,\" projected lottery pick Donovan Clingan told Yahoo Sports last month. \"The coaching staff got everything out of us and put us in the best position possible to be successful and succeed at a high level.\"\n\nCam Spencer, a projected second-round pick in this month's NBA Draft, transferred to UConn from Rutgers for his senior year and didn't hold back when asked why he chose coach Hurley and his program.\n\n\"There's definitely no *ss-kissing in the recruiting process, and that was my favorite part about it,\" Spencer told reporters during a media session at the Final Four. \"They're going to hold you accountable, they're going to tell you the truth about your strengths and weaknesses and where they see you fit in the program. I think that's one of the most special things about UConn, especially nowadays when kids want to hear all the things they're doing well, and the reality is you probably suck and need to get better in a lot of areas. That's the one thing I appreciate about Coach Hurley and our whole staff and just how honest they are with us as players.\"\n\nThe Huskies have a top-10 recruiting class coming in next year led by five-star wing Liam McNeeley and four-stars Isaiah Abraham and Ahmad Nowell. The most notable win was getting Alex Karaban to return for his junior year. The 6-foot-8 wing was one of the best players at the NBA Draft Combine last month, leading all players in the 3-point star drill, finishing 21-of-25. Karaban followed that up with two solid days of scrimmages where he was making good reads offensively and guarding the perimeter well. Many thought he would stay in this draft class with multiple teams interested in him as an early second-round pick, but he announced he would be going back to Storrs for another year right before the withdrawal deadline on May 29.\n\nTo leave with solid talent coming in and one of the team's best players returning for a chance at a three-peat would be extremely hard to walk away from.\n\nHurley has voiced his frustration with the college landscape and how out of control the transfer portal has gotten with over 1,000 players electing to transfer each year since the rule change in 2021. During his media availability prior to the championship game, Hurley was asked about motivation for his team when it has a huge target on its back, and he bluntly, and very honestly, cited the pains of the transfer portal.\n\n\"My biggest motivation for the last two to three weeks is that I don't want to deal with the portal s***,\" Hurley said. \"I can hide behind the fact that my season is still going on.\"\n\nHurley has been the biggest name in college coaching after his historic run at UConn and the way he's not only built championship teams, but also had success developing players for the NBA Draft. This year UConn has two projected lottery picks in Clingan and Stephon Castle, while Spencer and Tristen Newton could be drafted in the second round.\n\nImmediately following John Calipari's departure to Arkansas, Hurley became the top name to take over at Kentucky. He shut down any chance of that happening after the title game telling reporters with a laugh, \"I don't think that's a concern. You know my wife, you should have her answer that.\"\n\nTwo months later and his name is now in the mix for the hottest job in the NBA. The NBA is significantly different than college and especially the Lakers job with LeBron James and all the different personalities and egos in the locker room.\n\nIf Hurley does agree to become the next head coach of the Lakers on a long-term deal, he would be the future for VP and GM Rob Pelinka and governor Jeanie Buss, who would be looking further ahead than just the next two seasons. LeBron has said he doesn't have many years left. His son, Bronny, could be a second-round target for the Lakers in this year's draft. LeBron has said repeatedly that he wants to end his career sharing the court with his son. A rebuild for the Lakers could be two short years away and there's no coach that has been more successful in rebuilding a program and winning at the highest level in college than Hurley and he could very well bring the same success to the Lakers when the time comes.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Allegedly, the Los Angeles Lakers are pursuing UConn head coach, Dan Hurley, for the team's head coaching position. The Huskies head coach rose to fame after he recently led a previously struggling UConn programme to back-to-back national championships, making him one of the most sought-after basketball coaches globally.\n\nWhile the NBA world tries to speculate on the terms of Hurley's deal with the Lakers, former NBA guard Gilbert Arenas took the opportunity to troll his friend and ESPN analyst, JJ Redick, who was the frontrunner for the position before Hurley.\n\nTaking to X, Arenas posted a Jonathan Frakes \"You are wrong\" meme, showing his support for Hurley's appointment while making it clear that fans speculating about Redick's appointment are simply \"wrong\".\n\nNo surprise that Gilbert Arenas isn't backing his friend in his pursuit of becoming an NBA coach, at least not for the Lakers, as he wants them to pick up a legacy coach this time around, and not another rookie. Talking about it further on his show, Gils Arena, the former Washington Wizard said,\n\n\"Why is the Laker job the starting kit for everybody's career? This is supposed to be where we get the Mayweathers today, we dont want Mayweather going 0-0 and 1-0, let's get the great one.\"\n\nThe Lakers will surely have a great coach if they manage to land Hurley during this offseason. While things are still developing by the hour, LeBron James will have until June 29, to decide if he wants to opt into his player option or not, and with his son Bronny James still on the draft board, it will be interesting to see if the signing of Hurley pans out or not.\n\nESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski was among the first to break the news of Dan Hurley's possibly signing to the Lakers. With a few hours having passed since the news broke, the veteran reporter was back with another crucial piece of information. On ESPN, Woj wrote about the Lakers' situation with Hurley,\n\n\"The Los Angeles Lakers are targeting UConn men's basketball coach Dan Hurley as the franchise's next coach and are preparing a massive, long-term contract offer to bring the back-to-back NCAA national champion to the NBA.\"\n\nWojnarowski further reported that the Lakers have already interviewed a plethora of candidates for the role but have made it clear that Hurley will definitely be the team's front-runner for the position as things stand.\n\nThe two sides will reportedly escalate their discussions and negotiations over the {"uri": "8164899531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "14:51:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T14:51:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T14:50:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://sports.yahoo.com/coaching-the-lakers-is-a-hard-job-to-pass-up-except-maybe-dan-hurley-should-144536860.html", "title": "Coaching the Lakers is a hard job to pass up, except maybe Dan Hurley should", "body": "Earlier this week, during , UConn's Dan Hurley left open the possibility of one day leaving for the NBA.\n\nThe coach of college basketball's two-time reigning national champs said that UConn fits him perfectly but that he does aspire to test himself at the highest level \"if the right NBA situation were to come along.\"\n\nWhen Francesa expressed surprise, Hurley elaborated on what the \"right situation\" meant to him. He said it had to be a job \"where an organization wants a tone setter to come in and instill a culture. You know, young players and an organization that wants to pursue championships.\"\n\nThose comments took on newfound meaning early Thursday when ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski with the potential significant implications at both the NBA and college level. The Los Angeles Lakers are targeting Hurley as the franchise's next head coach and are preparing a massive, long-term contract offer, Wojnarowski reported.\n\nIt doesn't take a basketball savant to see why Hurley would be intrigued by the opportunity to coach the Lakers. This is maybe the premier job in basketball. It's a chance to guide a franchise that has captured 17 NBA championships, that has landed high-profile free agent after high-profile free agent and that has never hesitated to pay big-name coaches top dollar.\n\nPhil Jackson earned an annual salary of $12 million at the end of his Lakers tenure 13 years ago. Would it surprise anyone if the Lakers' offer to Hurley surpassed that?\n\nIt also helps that Hurley appears to have the approval of the most powerful man in the Lakers organization. In April, responding to an interview that JJ Redick did with Hurley for his podcast, LeBron James : \"He's so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff. Super creative with their O! Love it.\"\n\nThen there's the matter of how much more taxing and exhausting it is to be a college basketball coach today than it was even five years ago. Between the transfer portal and players gaining the potential to receive NIL money, recruiting is more intense and more round-the-clock. This past March, coaches whose teams were in the NCAA tournament were simultaneously raising NIL money, scouting and pursuing transfers and re-recruiting their own players.\n\nHurley himself joked about that on the eve of UConn's national title game showdown against Purdue two months ago. Asked about his biggest motivation during the NCAA tournament, a smiling Hurley quipped, \"I just don't want to deal with the portal s -- . That's why we're trying so hard to win right now.\"\n\n\"I'm seeing what other people are doing, and it's chaos,\" he added. \"I can hide behind, 'Hey, my season's still going on.'\"\n\nThose are all good reasons for Hurley to be tempted by the Lakers job -- but not necessarily for him to take it. He'd be risking a lot going to the Lakers and giving up even more if he leaves a UConn program that he himself has described as a perfect fit.\n\nHistory is littered with successful college basketball coaches who took a shot at leaping to the NBA but failed spectacularly.\n\nIn 1996, the New Jersey Nets hired John Calipari away from UMass on the heels of a Final Four run. The young, brash Calipari lasted only two-plus seasons with the Nets after rubbing veteran players and the New York media the wrong way on more than one occasion.\n\nIn 1997, the Boston Celtics plucked Rick Pitino from Kentucky after he won the 1996 national title and fell one win short of going back-to-back the following year. The result was a 102-146 record and\n\nJerry Tarkanian, Tim Floyd, Fred Hoiberg and Mike Montgomery had similar results. John Beilein somehow fared even worse. Only Billy Donovan and Brad Stevens achieved sustained success at the NBA level -- and even Donovan hasn't won a playoff series since his debut season in Oklahoma City nearly a decade ago.\n\nThe 51-year-old Hurley undeniably has the coaching acumen to thrive in the NBA and the authenticity and fiery demeanor to hold players accountable, but there's also no denying that he's quirky and that his temper burns hot. This is a guy whose practices are legendarily grueling; who searches for the slightest perceived slight to use as motivation; who rants and raves at referees after every close call.\n\nOn the sideline at UConn practices last fall were a set of cardboard posters representing every trophy that the Huskies could win during the upcoming season. Those posters took a beating from Hurley kicking them down or firing projectiles at them whenever he felt his team didn't practice up to its capabilities.\n\nHurley's hand-picked UConn players fed off his nonstop intensity. Would NBA veterans feel the same over the course of an 82-game schedule?\n\nThe Lakers' track record of burning through seven coaches in 13 years is also a red flag that Hurley shouldn't ignore. Frank Vogel lasted two seasons after winning a championship. Darvin Ham was ousted the year after reaching the Western Conference finals. Who's to say that Hurley wouldn't be scapegoated the first time things go awry?\n\nAt UConn, Hurley has the job security that comes with engineering the greatest two-year run in modern men's college basketball history.\n\nIn 2023, a UConn team led by , Andre Jackson and trounced its six NCAA tournament opponents by 20 points per game. Five of that team's top eight players moved on, yet last season's Huskies proved to be even more unbeatable, winning six NCAA tournament games by a record-setting 23.3 points apiece.\n\nThe college game may be tough on coaches these days, but Hurley has thrived better than anyone else amid the chaos. He has found a formula that works for him, sometimes passing on the most talented prospects in favor of team-first freshmen and transfers who prioritize winning and who aren't afraid to be coached hard.\n\nThanks to Hurley, UConn now has a chance to become the first program to three-peat since the heyday of John Wooden's UCLA dynasty. The Huskies are a fixture in way-too-early preseason top fives thanks to the return of standout forward Alex Karaban and the arrival of a bevy of accomplished newcomers.\n\nWhen speaking with Francesa earlier this week, Hurley acknowledged that leaving the northeast in general and UConn in particular would be hard for him. He said he hopes to stay \"as long as we're able to find these old school folks to bring into our program and then we just blend it with modern basketball.\"\n\n\"If we keep doing it like this,\" added Hurley, \"I'll stay here and the NBA will never be a thing.\"\n\nMaybe Hurley should take his own advice. Maybe he should leverage the Lakers' interest into a big raise and then stay where he is beloved.\n\nCoaching the Lakers is a job you can't pass up, except maybe Hurley should.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8165139948", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:42:49", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:42:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/sports/nba/who-dan-hurley-potential-next-head-coach-lakers-1909220", "title": "Who is Dan Hurley, The Potential Next Head Coach of the Lakers?", "body": "A bombshell report came out on Thursday morning regarding the Los Angeles Lakers' head coaching search.\n\nESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported the Lakers were preparing a \"massive, long-term offer\" to sway Connecticut head coach Dan Hurley to leave the NCAA level and come to the NBA.\n\nThis comes less than 24 hours after The Athletic's Shams Charania reported JJ Redick was the \"frontrunner\" for the L.A. head coaching vacancy.\n\nHurley comes with much more coaching experience than Redick, but neither of them has any at the professional level. While any announcement regarding Redick would have come after the NBA Finals -- since Redick is announcing them for ESPN -- a Hurley announcement could be finalized in the coming days.\n\nFans of college basketball are very familiar with Hurley, but the same might not be true for fans of the NBA. So, here's everything there is to know about Hurley, the potential next head coach of the Lakers.\n\nHurley, 51, was born in Jersey City, New Jersey in 1973. His father, Bob Hurley Sr., was a Hall of Fame high school basketball coach, and his brother, Bobby, is currently the head coach at Arizona State University.\n\nHurley played basketball under his father at St. Anthony High School, before playing at the collegiate level at Seton Hall University. After he finished his senior year, he immediately began a career in coaching.\n\nIn the 1996-97 season, Hurley was an assistant at his alma mater St. Anthony High School. In 1997, he was hired as an assistant at Rutgers University, where he stayed until 2001.\n\nIn 2001, Hurley got his first head coaching gig at Saint Benedict's Prep School, where he remained until 2010. He then got his first head coaching gig at the collegiate level with Wagner College, where he set the school's single-season win-loss record at 25-6.\n\nFrom Wagner, Hurley went to the University of Rhode Island, where he'd spend six seasons, leading them to the NCAA Tournament in his final two.\n\nOn March 22, 2018, Hurley was named the head coach at the University of Connecticut. In 2021 and 2022, he led them to the NCAA Tournament. And in 2023 and 2024, he led them to back-to-back NCAA Tournament wins.\n\nIn the 2022-23 season, Hurley led the Huskies to a surprise NCAA Tournament run as a No. 4 seed, beating the No. 5-seeded San Diego State Aztecs in the National Title game. In the 2023-24 season, the Huskies were much more dominant, winning a school-record 37 games en route to the No. 1 overall seed in the NCAA Tournament. UConn won every tournament game by double digits on their way to a second consecutive National Championship. They were one of the most dominant teams in NCAA history, and Hurley took home the Naismith College Coach of the Year award.\n\nLess than two months ago, at UConn's National Championship parade, Hurley emphatically exclaimed that he has no intentions of leaving the school for the foreseeable future.\n\n\"Maybe down the road, you hope you can mature enough emotionally to, much later in my career, to try to take a shot at the NBA -- down the road, way down the road,\" Hurley said following UConn's parade. \"I'm not going to coach anywhere else in college, unless UConn doesn't want me here.\"\n\nThat road could end up reaching a dead end sooner than expected, though, if Hurley elects to take the job with the Lakers.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8164662469", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:24:26", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:24:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T12:23:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/sport/article/2024/jun/06/lakers-reportedly-targeting-uconns-national-champion-coach-dan-hurley", "title": "Lakers reportedly targeting UConn's national champion coach Dan Hurley", "body": "Lakers parted ways with Darvin Ham in MayHurley known for developing player talent\n\nThe Los Angeles Lakers aim to hire Dan Hurley, who has led UConn to back-to-back NCAA national titles, as their next coach, according to ESPN.\n\nHurley is known for his tactical prowess as well as his ability to develop players, attributes that have made him the Lakers' top target as they seek to replace Darvin Ham, who was dismissed in May after the team lost in the first-round of the playoffs.\n\nHurley signed a six-year, $32m contract with UConn last year and ESPN reports the Lakers are offering him a lucrative, long-term deal. The Lakers are understood to have had preliminary discussion with the 51-year-old, who has spoken about his ambition to coach in the NBA, but are yet to make a formal offer.\n\nHurley's reputation for developing player talent may be a particular lure for the Lakers. New league rules make it harder for teams to be built around three star players, making developing younger players more important. Hurley could theoretically help improve talented younger players who are already on the Lakers roster, such as Austin Reaves, Rui Hachimura and Max Christie, behind their established stars, LeBron James and Anthony Davis. There have also been rumours in recent months that the Lakers could draft James's eldest son, Bronny, this year. Bronny is considered a marginal NBA talent but LeBron, who holds immense sway in the franchise, would be pleased at having Hurley involved in his son's development.\n\nJames has been open about his admiration for Hurley in the past. \"He's so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff. Super creative with their [offense].
