{"uri": "8165013344", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:08:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:08:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:07:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/40290192/dan-hurley-lakers-nba-uconn-coaching-decision", "title": "A college dynasty, LeBron's Lakers and a landscape-altering decision for Dan Hurley", "body": "Twenty years ago, the hottest coach in all of college basketball interviewed with the Los Angeles Lakers and made a choice that reverberated through two levels of basketball.\n\nDuke coach Mike Krzyzewski's flirtation with the franchise included a jaw-dropping five-year, $40 million offer that loomed as an industry paradigm-changer back in 2004.\n\nKrzyzewski obviously turned down the money and the overtures of Kobe Bryant, returned to Duke and left there as the winningest coach in college basketball history. The court there is named after him, and he is forever a part of the university's lore as a transformative figure.\n\nA generation later, UConn coach Dan Hurley faces a similar crossroads, as ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reports that Hurley is the target of the Lakers' coaching search. Hurley is fresh off back-to-back national titles -- Krzyzewski had gone back-to-back more than a decade before he made his decision -- and is the hottest coach in the sport.\n\nA fascinating choice awaits in a completely different era: possible collegiate immortality or the risk-reward of coaching the Lakers, which is equal parts sexy and volatile.\n\nCould the talented and impulsive Hurley rewire himself for the completely different temperament needed in the NBA? And is the college game as stable as the one Krzyzewski returned to 20 years ago?\n\nWill Hurley, 51, leave UConn in the middle of his prime and forgo the chance to chase John Wooden as the next NCAA tournament three-peat winner?\n\nWill Hurley take over the Lakers as they recalibrate in the twilight of LeBron James' career and attempt to skip the rebuild that could accompany his departure?\n\nWill Hurley look at the uncertain and disorganized moment of college basketball's nascent foray into becoming professional basketball and decide that actual professional basketball makes more sense?\n\nIt's impossible to overstate the stakes here. Hurley's decision ties the top college basketball program over the past quarter century -- UConn has won six national titles since 1999 -- with the future of the NBA's glitziest brand.\n\nWhat makes the decision for Hurley so compelling is that it's not an easy decision, as both sides have distinct pitfalls and payoffs.\n\nIf Hurley stays, he could go on to challenge Krzyzewski as the top modern coach in college basketball. Kansas' Bill Self (61) and St. John's Rick Pitino (71) are the only other current college coaches with multiple titles.\n\nPlanning the next 20 years in college, of course, comes with no certainty considering how much seismic change we've seen in the past five. Hurley would need to essentially re-recruit a new roster every year, deal with the vagaries of revenue sharing and NIL and hope the Big East can continue to swing with the two power conferences.\n\n(Hurley has not hid his disdain for the portal, summarized by this fetal position picture.)\n\nUConn doesn't have the ability to pay like the Lakers do, but it will be as fully committed as it possibly can be. The university's identity is wedded to big-time basketball. But over the next decade, when the Big East television contract is inevitably dwarfed by the SEC's and Big Ten's, could that become harder to do?\n\nNo one can safely predict what college sports will look like in 10 years, other than projecting that the football dollars of the SEC and Big Ten are going to drive those two leagues into a different financial stratosphere. No one is certain how that trickles down to hoops.\n\nAnd if there is some kind of breakaway of big-time football down the line, that's a whole other set of headaches. Ones that helped lead coaches Jay Wright, Roy Williams and Coach K to pick retirement over the collective migraines.\n\nBut Hurley's significant interest in the job indicates what's obvious to anyone who knows him -- he has the DNA of a Jersey street fighter. Sometimes that edge is his greatest strength, but in the NBA it could loom as the biggest risk in undercutting his tenure. The theater would be fascinating.\n\nThat street fighter will want him to face the challenge of going to the NBA, coaching the greatest modern player in the world and slaying the beast that is the Lakers job.\n\nBut that decision comes with the distinct risk of failure and a demand for Hurley to evolve immediately and significantly.\n\nHurley's players will tell you -- and we've had consecutive Final Four runs of testimonials -- that he brings the innate ability to be so relentlessly focused on winning and developing his players that it can be all-consuming. They balance that, of course, by saying he loves them up off the court. And no one, obviously, is going to argue with recent results.\n\nBut can Hurley rechannel that searing focus to the temperament of an NBA player? Could it work in the 82-game grind of an NBA season? The coaches aren't the stars in the NBA like they are in college. Can Hurley adjust to the whims of his players?\n\nThere's a successful path for Hurley to follow in college-to-NBA coaches such as Billy Donovan, Brad Stevens and Quin Snyder. They went to organizations that embraced the idea of running an NBA franchise like a college program, based heavily on player development and connection. The player development pedigree is there, and the tactical genius is atop college basketball right now.\n\nHurley gave one of the all-time self-evaluations during March when he summed up becoming one of the faces of college basketball this way: \"I'm basically a high school coach that's like masquerading up at this college level. I don't really care what people necessarily think of my intensity, it obviously shows up the right way with my team. We don't cheat, we don't lie. I think we're about all the right things. Just, at times, I'm an a--hole.\"\n\nWith a father, Bob, who is in the Basketball Hall of Fame as a coach and a brother, Bobby, who was a first-round NBA draft pick, the psychology of Hurley has always been fascinating. The flame running hot is hereditary and unflinching.\n\nBut there are two things about Hurley's self-assessed character trait that would need to unequivocally change, or his tenure would quickly become a repeat of the long line of college-to-NBA flops.\n\nThe first is Hurley would have to completely alter his sideline demeanor and his treatment of officials, as that act is completely unsustainable over the course of an NBA season.\n\nThat same intensity -- \"I am an obsessed coach,\" Hurley said in March -- that's been the North Star of a career rise from coaching in prep school has resulted in ugly and awkward interactions with officials. (Since Hurley arrived at UConn in 2018-19, the school is third in Division I with 25 technical fouls, per ESPN Stats & Information.)\n\nThe other is that he'd have to -- and it's weird to need to say this out loud -- stop interacting with and confronting fans. The site of Hurley yelling at Creighton and Providence fans postgame in the final months of the season -- it's all on YouTube -- would go from local eye roll to national roasting.\n\nIf those same interactions happen after an overtime buzzer-beater in Sacramento, it'd be a viral monster and the biggest story in sports the next day. Not just a shoulder shrug about \"Danny being Danny.\"\n\nUltimately, the choice comes down to this: Stay at a place where you are cherished, your antics are shrugged off and your legacy can echo for generations.\n\nOr you can go to the Lakers, where winning big crosses into pop culture, allows you to tango with Hollywood and compete at the highest level in a more stable league.\n\nAny risk is mitigated, of course, by the fact that some SEC or Big Ten school would embrace his failure for $10 million per year in 2026. And he could go on his merry obsessive ways, winning games and reviving his Hall of Fame track. All while expressing the same level of histrionics toward the officials.\n\nTwo decades after Krzyzewski chose Duke, another choice looms that will ripple through two billion-dollar industries.", "source": {"uri": "africa.espn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ESPN.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UConn_Huskies_men's_basketball", "type": "wiki", He has said his goal is to coach in the NBA one day.\n\nHurley, 51, has posted a 141-58 record while leading UConn to four NCAA Tournament appearances during his six seasons with UConn. He had a 38-23 record during two seasons as the head coach at Wagner (2010-12) and a 113-82 mark in six campaigns with Rhode Island.\n\nHurley also has a fan in LeBron James, as the Lakers superstar praised the coach over social media on April 19.\n\n\"He's so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff. Super creative with their (offense). Love it,\" James wrote.\n\nLos Angeles fired Darvin Ham on May 3 after two seasons, including an appearance in the Western Conference finals in 2023.\n\nThe Lakers finished the regular season with a 47-35 mark, good enough for only an eighth-place finish in the Western Conference. {"uri": "8165144226", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:45:14", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:45:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:44:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://apnews.com/article/lakers-hurley-redick-coaching-search-9a6042c255d469151326cbaa13ae27f0", "title": "Lakers conduct a public coaching search, considering Redick and Hurley, in hopes of pleasing LeBron", "body": "LOS ANGELES (AP) -- The Los Angeles Lakers' coaching search has been very public, seemingly chaotic and dominated by famous names.\n\nTotally Hollywood, in other words.\n\nThe Lakers' reported plan to offer a massive contract to UConn coach Dan Hurley is the latest twist in the monthlong race to replace Darvin Ham, who was fired May 3 after two seasons.\n\nThe Lakers were knocked out of the first round of the current playoffs, but the 17-time NBA champion franchise has nicely filled the void of hoops drama during the week before the NBA Finals with steady leaks about the progress of their quest for a coach who can win a title -- and almost as vitally, a coach who can entice LeBron James to finish his career in purple and gold.\n\nAccording to a person with knowledge of the lengthy search, the Lakers have strongly considered J.J. Redick, the former player and current ESPN analyst who does a podcast with James; Hurley, the back-to-back national championship-winning coach of the Huskies; and James Borrego, the respected former Charlotte Hornets coach and ex-Gregg Popovich assistant who spent last season on New Orleans' staff.\n\nThe person spoke on condition of anonymity because the Lakers aren't commenting publicly on the search to replace Ham.\n\nBut they sure are commenting privately.\n\nOn Wednesday, The Athletic reported that Redick shockingly was the frontrunner despite his total lack of coaching experience. On Thursday, the search took another wild turn when ESPN reported the Lakers were instead targeting Hurley, whose candidacy hadn't even been mentioned in many discussions of the job.\n\nThe crazy twists are representative of the various factions within the Lakers brain trust of owner Jeanie Buss and general manager Rob Pelinka dispensing narratives to their favored media outlets. The Lakers previously seemed unlikely to make an official hire before the end of the NBA Finals, but the person who spoke to the AP said even that could change, depending on their progress.\n\nWhile the Dallas Mavericks and the Boston Celtics waited a week to begin the NBA Finals, the Lakers have dominated talk radio, television and message boards with speculation on the best choice to lead James and the Lakers back to contention for a second title together.\n\nThe Lakers are making their coaching change at a critical juncture for the franchise's partnership with the NBA's career scoring leader.\n\nThe 39-year-old James just completed his 21st season while playing at a higher level than anyone with that much experience in basketball history, but he has until June 29 to decide whether to exercise his $51.4 million player option for the 2024-25 season.\n\nJames could take the deal, or he could sign an even bigger new contract for more years -- or he could become a free agent for the first time in six years.\n\nWhile 31-year-old Anthony Davis is the Lakers' foundation with a long-term contract in Los Angeles, Buss and Pelinka are clearly determined to keep James alongside him for as long as possible -- even publicly floating their willingness to draft his son, Bronny, who just completed one brief collegiate season at USC.\n\nWhile agent Rich Paul has said James is not involved in the coaching search as he prepares to play for the U.S. at the Paris Olympics, the Lakers' candidates seem designed to appeal to him.\n\nJames' connection with Redick is well-known. James also recently praised Hurley on social media following a podcast interview between Redick and Hurley, with the 20-time All-Star writing that Hurley is \"so DAMN GOOD!!! Along with his staff. Super creative with their (offense). Love it.\"\n\nHurley has won 141 games in six seasons at UConn, rolling to the past two national titles in impressive fashion. The addition of the nation's top collegiate coach to the Lakers could be enticing to James and his son, who likely still needs extensive development to be a serviceable NBA player.\n\nThe Lakers' relative underachievement this season despite a healthy James and Davis was primarily blamed on Ham, the first-time head coach who dismayed many fans and observers with his rotations, preparation and strategic acumen. The Lakers have chased savvy basketball minds in their latest search, no matter their pedigree: Redick's encyclopedic understanding of the game has been on display in his podcast with James, while Hurley favors an NBA-friendly style of play that should translate well to the biggest basketball stage.\n\nWhoever they choose, the Lakers will be adding yet another head coach at a pace typically reserved for underachieving European soccer teams, not powerhouse NBA franchises.\n\nThe new hire will be the Lakers' eighth coach since Phil Jackson's departure in 2011 and their fourth coach since James arrived as a free agent in 2018. Frank Vogel led Los Angeles to the 2020 championship, but kept the job for only 225 games over three seasons before being fired exactly 18 months after raising the trophy in the Florida bubble.\n\nHam was the fourth coach fired by James' teams in the past eight years, joining Cleveland's David Blatt and the Lakers' Luke Walton and Vogel.", "source": {"uri": "apnews.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8164733758", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:08:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:08:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:07:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.on3.com/news/pete-thamel-dan-hurley-nba-speculation-a-sign-college-basketball-is-year-to-year-business/", "title": "Pete Thamel: Dan Hurley NBA speculation a sign college basketball is 'year-to-year business'", "body": "Thursday morning began like many crazy NBA offseason days over the years, with a massive report from Adrian Wojnarowski in the wee hours. That report being that UConn coach Dan Hurley could be headed to the Los Angeles Lakers.\n\nOf course, Hurley is fresh off back-to-back national titles with the Huskies and just turned down a reportedly huge offer from Kentucky a couple months back. Now, it's an even bigger basketball giant, the Lakers, who are preparing to godfather offer to top coach in college hoops.\n\nWhen discussing this potential move on Get Up, host Mike Greenberg invited college sports insider Pete Thamel onto the show to explain why a jump to the NBA could be appealing for Hurley given the nature of modern collegiate athletics.\n\n\"Well, I think Dan Hurley accidentally summed this up for you Greenie,\" said Thamel. \"A couple weeks after they won the title, he tweeted out 'Portal Day 1' and it's a picture of him lying in the fetal position in his office having to deal with that.\"\n\nDespite his immense success in the current era, perhaps Hurley still doesn't love the turnstile nature of roster construction nowadays.\n\n\"I think what Dan Hurley is saying is college basketball is a year-to-year business,\" added Thamel. \"Your roster one season has very little to do with your roster the next season. I think if you walk in the average American sports bar right now and ask 'can you name five college basketball players for next year?' -- I don't think anyone can unless they're a hardcore message board fan.\"\n\nWith the decreasing amount of stars who actually return to their schools the next season, Thamel thinks coaches like Hurley have and will grow tired of keeping up on a yearly basis.\n\n\"That constant churn and constant turnover makes it challenging to do what Dan Hurley does so well -- run a program, be a program-builder -- when you have all these new starters. And then your roster is 80% different every year. That becomes taxing and unsustainable over a long period of time if you're going to pour into these players and have your program built on development.\"\n\nAll that to say: with personnel decisions out of his control in the NBA, the focus is solely on coaching ball, which is where Hurley wants it. Sure, he'd have less control in LA than in Storrs, but the opportunity to lead arguably basketball's biggest worldwide brand is hard to pass up.", "source": {"uri": "on3.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8164579331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "11:36:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T11:36:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:34:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.nj.com/sports/2024/06/lakers-targeting-uconns-dan-hurley-with-long-term-massive-offer-they-are-going-to-make-it-very-hard-for-dan-hurley-to-say-no.html", "title": "Lakers targeting UConn's Dan Hurley with 'long-term, massive' offer: 'They are going to make it very hard for Dan Hurley to say no'", "body": "The Los Angeles Lakers are targeting UConn coach Dan Hurley with a \"long-term\" and \"massive\" offer to become their next head coach, \"and they are going to make it very hard for Dan Hurley to say no,\" ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported Thursday morning on SportsCenter.\n\nThe Lakers parted ways with Darvin Ham last month and are still seeking a replacement as LeBron James heads into his age-40 season.\n\nHurley, one of only three living coaches to win back-to-back NCAA championships, must now decide whether to make the jump to the NBA from the college ranks, following the likes of former Florida coach Billy Donovan, who won back-to-back titles at Florida and now coaches with the Chicago Bulls. He has a loaded team and is eyeing a three-peat in the college ranks.\n\nHurley, the Jersey City native and former Seton Hall guard, was targeted by Kentucky before the school eventually hired Mark Pope, but an offer from the Lakers is something entirely different.\n\n\"This for Dan Hurley has really been the ultimate mountain top, the chance to coach in the NBA,\" Woj said. \"There's no bigger stage, there's no bigger seat in coaching than the Lakers and Dan Hurley's intentions right now are to hear the Lakers out and they're going to talk more extensively here in the next few days, I'm told.\"\n\nDenver Nuggets coach Michael Malone told NJ Advance Media last month that he believes Hurley could be an excellent NBA coach.\n\n\"Do I think he could coach in the NBA? Of course, I can, he's a hell of a coach,\" Malone told NJ Advance Media in April\n\n\"There's always been [questions], 'Can a European coach coach in the NBA? Can a college coach coach in the NBA?' and you look at some of the guys that have tried and maybe it hasn't worked out. Danny played the game, he knows the game, he grew up in the gym.\"\n\nAsked if Dan Hurley would have to tone down some of his sideline antics, including his constant working of the officials, to be an NBA coach, Malone had some words of wisdom.\n\n\"Does he have to tone down?\" Malone said. \"At the end of the day, it all depends on your team and your players.\n\n\"When I got the job in Sacramento, my first head job [in the NBA] and coach [Gregg] Popovich was a big part of me getting that job, and he called me up and said, 'Listen, congratulations. This is really important. You gotta be yourself, you can't be somebody you're not. But the biggest thing is as you are yourself, you can only get away with that.'\n\n'For me being emotional-Irish, Pop being emotional-Serbian, Danny being him, you can only get away with that if you're players know that you care about them. His players at UConn know that he cares about them. Is he tough, is he demanding? Yes, he is, but he wants the best for them. And it's helped them win at a high level.\n\n\"I think if Danny Hurley got into the NBA, there's on doubt he can coach. You watch their team play. People talk about their offense, to me I was more impressed with how they defended all over the place. It was really fun to watch that finals game against Purdue and their defensive game plan.\n\n\"I have no doubt that Danny Hurley could step into the NBA and find a way to connect to his group and do a good job because Danny is a coach. He's a teacher of the game, he's a coach of the game and he's had a tremendous amount of success.\"\n\nThis is a developing story. Stay tuned for updates.\n\nThank you for relying on us to provide the journalism you can trust. LeBron James will become a free agent this summer.\n\nA potential Hurley departure would be another blow for college basketball, which has seen a slew of legendary coaches from Mike Krzyzewski to Jay Wright leave the sport in recent years as its undergone significant upheaval with the transfer portal and NIL payments.\n\nThe Lakers are in the market for a new coach after firing Saginaw native {"uri": "8164767152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:28:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:28:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:27:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.espn.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/40290192/dan-hurley-lakers-nba-uconn-coaching-decision", "title": "A college dynasty, LeBron's Lakers and a landscape-altering decision for Dan Hurley", "body": "Twenty years ago, the hottest coach in all of college basketball interviewed with the Los Angeles Lakers and made a choice that reverberated through two levels of basketball.\n\nDuke coach Mike Krzyzewski's flirtation with the franchise included a jaw-dropping five-year, $40-million offer that loomed as an industry paradigm changer back in 2004.\n\nKrzyzewski obviously turned down the money and the overtures of Kobe Bryant, returned to Duke and left there as the winningest coach in college basketball history. He has the court named after him and is forever a part of the university's lore as a transformative figure.\n\nA generation later, UConn coach Dan Hurley faces a similar crossroads. He's fresh off back-to-back national titles -- Krzyzewski had gone back-to-back more than a decade before -- and is the hottest coach in the sport.\n\nA fascinating choice looms in a completely different era: collegiate immortality or the risk-reward of coaching the Lakers, which looms as equal parts sexy and volatile.\n\nCould the talented and impulsive Hurley re-wire himself for the completely different temperament needed in the NBA? And is the college game as stable as the one Krzyzewski returned to 20 years ago?\n\nWith ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reporting that Hurley is the target of the Lakers coaching search, a generationally impactful decision again looms over two sports. Will the hottest coach in college basketball leave for the NBA's most iconic coaching job?\n\nWill Hurley, 51, leave UConn in the middle of his prime and forgo the chance to chase John Wooden as the next NCAA tournament three-peat winner?\n\nWill Hurley take over the Lakers as they recalibrate in the twilight of LeBron James' career and attempt to skip the rebuild that could accompany his departure?\n\nWill Hurley look at the uncertain and disorganized moment of college basketball's nascent foray into becoming professional basketball and decide that actual professional basketball makes more sense?\n\nIt's impossible to overstate the stakes here. Hurley's decision ties the top college basketball program over the last quarter century -- UConn has won six national titles since 1999 -- with the future of the NBA's glitziest brand.\n\nWhat makes the decision for Hurley so compelling is that it's not an easy decision, as both sides have distinct pitfalls and payoffs.\n\nIf Hurley stays, he could go on and challenge Krzyzewski as the top modern coach in college basketball. Kansas' Bill Self (61) and St. John's Rick Pitino (71) are the only other current college coaches with multiple titles.\n\nPlanning the next 20 years in college, of course, comes with no certainty considering how much seismic change we've seen in the last five. Hurley would need to essentially re-recruit a new roster every year, deal with the vagaries of revenue share and NIL and hope the Big East can continue to swing with the two power conferences.\n\n(Hurley has not hid his disdain for the portal, summarized by this fetal position picture.)\n\nUConn doesn't have the ability to pay like the Lakers do, but it will be as fully committed as it possibly can be. The university's identity is wedded to big-time basketball, but at some point over the next decade with the Big East television contract inevitably dwarfed by the SEC and Big Ten, could that become harder to do?\n\nNo one can safely predict what college sports will look like in 10 years, other than projecting that the football dollars of the SEC and Big Ten are going to drive those two leagues further into a different financial stratosphere. No one is certain how that trickles to hoops.\n\nAnd if there's some kind of breakaway of big-time football down the line, that's a whole other set of headaches. Ones that helped lead Jay Wright, Roy Williams and Coach K to pick retirement over the collective migraines.\n\nBut Hurley's significant interest in the job indicates what's obvious to anyone who knows him -- he's got the DNA of a Jersey street fighter. Sometimes that edge is his greatest strength, but in the NBA it could loom as the biggest risk in undercutting his tenure. The theater would be fascinating.\n\nThat streetfighter will want him to face the challenge of going to the NBA, coaching the greatest modern player in the world and slaying the beast that is the Lakers job.\n\nBut that decision comes with the distinct risk of failure and a demand for Hurley to evolve immediately and significantly.\n\nHurley's players will tell you -- and we've had consecutive Final Four runs of testimonials -- that he brings the innate ability to be so relentlessly focused on winning and developing his players that it can be all consuming. They balance that, of course, by saying he loves them up off the court. And no one, obviously, is going to argue with recent results.\n\nBut can Hurley re-channel that searing focus to the temperament of an NBA player? Could it work in the 82-game grind of an NBA season? The coaches aren't the stars in the NBA like they are in college. Can Hurley adjust to the whims of his players?\n\nThere's a path for Hurley to follow the successful path of college-to-NBA coaches like Billy Donovan, Brad Stevens and Quin Snyder. They went to organizations that embraced the idea of running an NBA franchise like a college program, based heavily on player development and connection. The player development pedigree is there, and the tactical genius is atop college basketball right now.\n\nHurley gave one of the all-time self-evaluations during March when he summed up becoming one of the faces of college basketball this way: \"I'm basically a high school coach that's like masquerading up at this college level. I don't really care what people necessarily think of my intensity, it obviously shows up the right way with my team. We don't cheat, we don't lie. I think we're about all the right things. Just, at times, I'm an a--hole.\"\n\nWith a father, Bob, who is in the Basketball Hall of Fame as a coach and a brother, Bobby, who was a first-round NBA draft pick, the psychology of Hurley has always been fascinating. The flame running hot is hereditary and unflinching.\n\nBut there are two things about Hurley's self-assessed character trait that would need to unequivocally change, or his tenure would quickly become a repeat of the long line of college-to-NBA flops.\n\nThe first is Hurley would have to completely alter his sideline demeanor and his treatment of officials, as that act is completely unsustainable over the course of an NBA season.\n\nThat same intensity -- \"I am an obsessed coach,\" Hurley said in March -- that's been the north star of a career rise from coaching in prep school has resulted in ugly and awkward interactions with officials. (Since Hurley arrived at UConn in 2018-19, the school is third in Division I with 25 technical fouls, per ESPN Stats & Info.)\n\nThe other is that he'd have to -- and it's weird to need to say this out loud -- stop interacting with and confronting fans. The site of Hurley yelling at Creighton and Providence fans postgame in the final months of the season -- it's all on YouTube -- would go from local eye roll to national roasting.\n\nIf those same interactions happen after an overtime buzzer beater in Sacramento, it'd be a viral monster and the biggest story in sports the next day. Not just a shoulder shrug about \"Danny being Danny.\"\n\nUltimately, the choice comes down to this: Stay at a place where you are cherished, your antics are shrugged off and your legacy can echo for generations.\n\nOr you can go to the Lakers, where winning big crosses into pop culture, allows you to tango with Hollywood and compete at the highest level in a more stable league.\n\nAny risk is mitigated, of course, by the fact that some SEC or Big Ten school would embrace his failure for $10 million per year in 2026. And he could go on his merry obsessive ways, winning games and reviving his Hall of Fame track. All while expressing the same level of histrionics toward the officials.\n\nTwo decades after Krzyzewski's chose Duke, another choice looms that will ripple through two billion-dollar industries.", Sources told Shams Charania of The Athletic that the ESPN broadcaster and former NBA veteran was the front-runner for the head coaching job in recent days. Hurley has previously been interviewed by Redick for a podcast, prompting a glowing reply from James on social media.\n\nThe 51-year-old compiled an impressive 141-58 record in six seasons with the Huskies, including a remarkable 68-11 mark over the past two years en route to two national titles.\n\nHurley was at the center of the Kentucky coaching search after John Calipari left for Arkansas, but he opted to stay at UConn, citing a desire to go for a three-peat and proximity to his family in New Jersey as major factors in his decision.\n\nThe Lakers fired head coach Darwin Ham after two The Lakers must've made an incredibly aggressive offer to pull off this massive hire.\n\nWojnarowski continues in his report, stating that Hurley was always at the top of the Lakers' search.", {"uri": "8164932676", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:17:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:17:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:12:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.postandcourier.com/arena/the-spun/dan-hurleys-wife-has-a-big-preference-for-where-she-wants-to-live/article_7fb12776-1b93-5d59-b3b1-d30c9afac3b5.html", "title": "Dan Hurley's Wife Has A Big Preference For Where She Wants To Live", "body": "Dan Hurley appears to be on the verge of landing the head coaching job with the Los Angeles Lakers, but is his wife going to sign off on the move?\n\nAndrea Hurley, the wife of the UConn Huskies national title-winning head coach, is a New Jersey native. When Dan Hurley was linked to the Kentucky Wildcats job, he used his wife - and her living preferences - as a reason for why he stayed put at UConn.\n\n\"We just went to Rhode Island, which I had to drag her to, and then to Connecticut, I got her closer (to New Jersey). I can't afford a divorce right now, I just started making money,\" he said of his wife back in April.\n\nDan Hurley met his wife, Andrea, during their time together at Seton Hall. They both grew up in New Jersey. The couple has two sons, with Andrew Hurley walking on to play for his dad at UConn.\n\nNBA fans are speculating about Andrea Hurley's preference for the next move, if it happens.\n\n\"Hurley's decision comes down to whether his wife wants to go west. Remember, when Hurley spoke to Kentucky, his wife wanted to stay closer to Jersey. Lakers are different than Kentucky. Plus Bron will love the hire not only for his son's development but they'll actually know what to do because of culture/system,\" one fan wrote.\n\n\"Hot take. Hurley isn't leaving. He got AK back. He has a solid team. His wife doesn't wanna move again. He's a loyalty guy and is fielding offers like anyone would,\" one fan added.\n\nThe Lakers is about as tempting of an NBA coaching job as there is, though. Perhaps the allure of Los Angeles - and the money the Lakers can offer - will be too much for the Hurley family to pass up.", "source": {"uri": "postandcourier.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Post {"uri": "8165181593", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "18:16:36", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T18:16:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T18:14:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.si.com/college-basketball/what-happens-to-uconn-if-dan-hurley-leaves-for-the-lakers", "title": "What Happens to UConn If Dan Hurley Leaves for the Lakers", "body": "Dan Hurley is reportedly a front-runner for the Los Angeles Lakers head coaching job. / Robert Deutsch-USA TODAY Sports\n\nDan Hurley, fresh off two straight national championships with the UConn Huskies, could be on the move.\n\nESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski reported Thursday morning the Los Angeles Lakers are targeting Hurley to replace Darvin Ham as the organization's next head coach, with talks expected to \"escalate in coming days\" as part of a \"relentless\" pursuit of college basketball's hottest coach. Such a move would be a seismic one, particularly in the college game, where Hurley has built a budding dynasty at UConn and has rapidly entered the conversation for being the best coach in college basketball.\n\nHere's how such a move would impact UConn and what to look out for in the coming days should Hurley head to the NBA.\n\nThe beauty of the UConn job is very much in the eye of the beholder. On fundamentals alone, the job is less attractive than other blue bloods, given its location and the lack of big-time football money flowing through it, along with the subsequent long-term conference affiliation questions that come with that. Despite that, no program has had more success in the 2000s than UConn, winning national championships under three different coaches (two each by Hurley and Jim Calhoun, one by Kevin Ollie). The expectations for whoever would come next are national championships, plural. That's a daunting task, especially given a potentially bearish financial future compared to the program's peers in leagues with eight- and nine-figure annual television payouts coming soon.\n\nThe job opening in early June also presents problems. Wooing top coaches who've already built rosters for next season would be tricky and potentially complicated further by recent contract extensions that have ballooned buyouts into the $10 million or more range. A coach from outside the UConn family would also have his hands full retaining the current roster, a priority given UConn's legitimate aspirations for a three-peat.\n\nThat makes an internal promotion perhaps the most realistic option, either on an interim basis for a year or on a full-time basis. UConn has two strong candidates on its current staff in associate head coach Kimani Young and assistant coach Luke Murray. The perceived favorite would be Young, who took over coaching duties when Hurley was ejected in a famous 2022 game against the Villanova Wildcats and owns the top title on staff. Young has long been due for a head coaching opportunity and has been openly praised by Hurley several times for his work both in game-planning and recruiting.\n\nMurray, an X-and-O savant and the son of actor Bill Murray, could also emerge as a potential candidate. If not tabbed the head coach, Hurley seems likely to push for him to join his Lakers staff.\n\nIf a full search were opened up, it'd be fascinating to see which candidates emerge. Rutgers's Steve Pikiell was on the board when Hurley took the job and he played and coached under Calhoun, but has his most talented team yet set to enroll at Rutgers this summer. Another regionally tied name that could make sense is Seton Hall's Shaheen Holloway, who went to an Elite Eight as the head coach at St. Peter's. Athletic director David Benedict could also take big swings at the likes of Auburn's Bruce Pearl (a Massachusetts native) and Alabama's Nate Oats (who previously worked in New York at Buffalo), but neither seems likely to land.\n\nIf Hurley leaves, every player on the Huskies would have a 30-day window to enter the transfer portal despite the portal being otherwise closed since May 1. Hurley rebuilt the Huskies' roster this spring to have a chance to contend for a three-peat, reeling in highly regarded transfers Aidan Mahaney and Tarris Reed Jr., five-star freshman Liam McNeeley and retaining star forward Alex Karaban. A swift internal hire could help retain the current roster, though it isn't a guarantee. Even with an internal hire made for 2023-24 after Bob Huggins was fired at West Virginia last June, five players entered the portal, with three eventually leaving.\n\nGiven the way prices in the NIL market have exploded for top transfers as supply has shrunk in the last month, it's safe to say there would be hugely lucrative offers on the table to try to woo UConn's current roster into the portal. How Benedict handles this search could be the difference between the Huskies being deep in contention for a third straight championship and facing a near-impossible rebuild in June after a significant roster exodus.\n\nIn an era of significant turnover among the sport's legendary coaches, Hurley had emerged as one of the new faces of the game. His fiery personality and ever-quotable news conferences, combined with the remarkable success of the last two years, gave Hurley the chance to take over the sport and become this generation's John Wooden or Mike Krzyzewski. To lose Hurley to the NBA would be a brutal break for a sport hunting for star power for fans to attach themselves to.\n\nPlus, UConn going for a historic third straight title would be one of the biggest stories of the 2024-25 season. That pursuit being derailed in June by a coaching search would be a crippling blow months before the season tips off.", "source": {"uri": "si.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sports Illustrated"}, {"uri": "8164796476", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "13:46:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T13:46:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T13:45:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.sportico.com/personalities/coaches/2024/dan-hurley-lakers-uconn-contract-buyout-salary-1234783106/", "title": "Hurley Would Owe UConn $1.9M for Lakers Jump, $7.5M for College Move", "body": "Dan Hurley would owe UConn $1.875 million if he leaves to coach the Los Angeles Lakers, who are reportedly interested in hiring the Naismith College Coach of the Year. But taking another NCAA gig would cost Hurley -- or his new employer -- significantly more.\n\nHurley last year signed a six-year, $32.1 million employment contract that runs through March of 2029. The deal, a copy of which was obtained by Sportico via records request, includes two parallel payment structures should he leave early: one for NBA jobs, and one for other D1 college jobs. In contrast to the $1.875 million owed if he goes to an NBA team, Hurley would owe UConn $7.5 million if he left the school tomorrow for another NCAA gig.\n\nWriting these buyouts into coaches' contracts is a common way that schools protect themselves from in-demand coaches raising their profiles and leaving for other opportunities. Hurley has coached the Huskies for the past six years, leading UConn to four NCAA tournaments and back-to-back national championships in 2023 and 2024.\n\nHowever, it's rare for the buyouts to distinguish between college and NBA jobs. (Hurley's previous UConn contract made no such distinction.) These fees are often paid by the team doing the hiring and are another part of the calculus of landing their desired candidate. When UConn hired Hurley in 2018, for example, the school paid his $1 million buyout at Rhode Island, while also including language in his contract which said the school would also neutralize any tax obligations associated with the payment.\n\nThe Lakers are \"targeting\" Hurley as their next coach, ESPN reported Thursday morning. The story says the NBA team, whose roster includes LeBron James, is \"preparing a massive, long-term contract offer,\" though it did not provide any specifics. The highest-paid coaches in the NBA make more than $10 million, according to Sportico's calculations, a bit more than Kansas's Bill Self, the top-paid coach in college. San Antonio Spurs coach Gregg Popovich leads the way at $16 million, followed by Monty Williams of the Detroit Pistons at $13.1 million.\n\nHurley's contract -- which he signed last June, after his first NCAA title but before his second -- paid him about $4.9 million this past year, including a $500,000 retention bonus paid in November. That doesn't include a $500,000 bonus for winning the national title and a handful of other performance bonuses.\n\nESPN said the Lakers have already made preliminary contact with Hurley. A representative for the Lakers didn't immediately respond to a request for comment. An email sent to Hurley's UConn address wasn't returned.\n\nEarlier this year, Hurley was asked about the possibility of his leaving UConn. He joked that he wouldn't ask his wife, a New Jersey native, to relocate. He then added that he was focused on winning a third straight national title. \"I mean, we just went to Rhode Island, which I had to drag her to, and then to Connecticut,\" he said, according to ESPN. \"I got her closer [to New Jersey]. And now further? I can't afford a divorce right now, too. I don't know how you're at the best mid-major program in the country, or a high major, and not wanting your program to look like our program.\"\n\nGiven the school's massive success behind Hurley's staff, an internal replacement would make sense if the Lakers rumors become a reality. {"uri": "2024-06-380818070", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "12:00:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T12:00:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T11:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.aol.com/sports/report-lakers-targeting-uconns-dan-110739522.html", "title": "Report: Lakers targeting UConn's Dan Hurley for head coaching job", "body": "According to ESPN, the Los Angeles Lakers are targeting Hurley as the team's next coach. UConn has won back-to-back NCAA tournaments under Hurley over the last two seasons. The Lakers are looking for a coach to replace Darvin Ham after getting eliminated in the first round of the playoffs by the Denver Nuggets this spring.\n\nFormer Duke and NBA player J.J. Redick had been seen as the frontrunner for the Lakers job in recent days. But the Lakers are reportedly preparing to offer Hurley a \"massive\" contract for him to come to the NBA.\n\nHurley, 51, would take over a team that's looking for one more push to the Finals with LeBron James and Anthony Davis. After winning the 2020 NBA Finals, the Lakers have lost twice in the first round of the playoffs and missed the postseason in 2022. In Ham's first season in 2022-23, the Lakers got the No. 7 seed and advanced to the Western Conference Finals before getting swept by the Nuggets.\n\nJames, who turns 40 in December, has a player option on his contract for the 2024-25 season that needs to be picked up by June 29. On the assumption that it's picked up -- there are no signs he will not -- James and Davis will make a combined $90 million next season.\n\nThere's limited financial and roster flexibility for the Lakers beyond James and Davis too. The team does have its 2024 first-round pick at No. 17 after the Pelicans opted to gamble on the Lakers' roster and take the team's 2025 first-round pick earlier this summer as part of the deal for Davis. With that pick, the team's 2029 first-round pick and other players on the roster, Los Angeles could be in the market to upgrade for a No. 3 player alongside its star duo.\n\nHowever, a move for another top-tier player could significantly hurt the team's depth and force the Lakers to rely on minimum-salary players for a large portion of the roster. Just ask the Phoenix Suns how that went this season. The Suns were bounced in the first round by the Minnesota Timberwolves in the first season with Kevin Durant, Devin Booker and Bradley Beal all on the same team.\n\nHurley is 292-163 as a college coach\n\nHurley has won nearly 300 games across 14 seasons as a head coach at the top level of men's college basketball. After two seasons at Wagner, Hurley took over at Rhode Island. He turned the Rams into a 23-win team in his third season after Rhode Island went 8-21 in year one.\n\nAfter taking the Rams to back-to-back NCAA tournaments in 2017 and 2018, Hurley was hired at UConn. The Huskies were a mess when he was brought in. UConn had finished under .500 in each of the past two seasons and had made just one NCAA tournament appearance since winning the national title in 2014.\n\nUConn was 16-17 in Hurley's first season before winning 19 games in year two before the COVID-19 pandemic prematurely ended the college basketball season. Since then, UConn has made the NCAA tournament four straight times and UConn has become the prominent program in men's college basketball.\n\nThe Huskies have obliterated their opponents in each of the past two NCAA tournaments. In 2023, UConn beat every team it played in the tournament by at least 13 points on the way to a national title win over San Diego State.\n\nThe recent history of college coaches heading to the NBA\n\nUConn was even better in 2023-24. The Huskies lost just three games all season and beat their NCAA tournament opponents by even more. UConn won each of its six tournament games by at least 14 points. The Huskies beat Alabama 86-72 in the Final Four before beating Purdue 75-60 in the national title game.\n\nIf Hurley heads to the NBA, he would be the first NCAA tournament-winning coach to go from the college ranks to the NBA since Billy Donovan left Florida for the Oklahoma City Thunder after the 2014-15 college basketball season. Florida won back-to-back national titles in 2006 and 2007 under Donovan and made the Final Four in 2014.\n\nDonovan is still in the league with the Chicago Bulls, though Chicago hasn't been past the first round of the playoffs in his four years with the team. And he's a relative outlier among coaches who have made the leap in both success and tenure.\n\nThe same year Donovan was hired by the Thunder, the Bulls hired Fred Hoiberg from Iowa State. The Bulls were 40 games under .500 in three-plus seasons under Hoiberg and he's now the coach at Nebraska.\n\nSince Donovan and Hoiberg, just one college coach has been hired by an NBA team. The Cleveland Cavaliers hired Michigan's John Beilein in 2019, but he lasted just 54 games as the team's head coach. Cleveland went 14-40 in his short time with the team.\n\nOutside of Donovan, the most successful NBA coach to make the leap from the college ranks in modern history is Boston Celtics executive Brad Stevens. After back-to-back Final Fours at Butler in 2010 and 2011, Stevens was hired by the Boston Celtics as the team's head coach in 2013.\n\nOver eight seasons with the Celtics, Stevens was 354-282 as a head coach and Boston twice won more than 50 games in that span. He moved into the front office after the 2020-21 season and is currently the Celtics' president of basketball operations.", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": Obviously, we spoiled ourselves and we've spoiled our fans with how well we've played and the run we're on, but I do think we believe as an organization that we can continue to stay where we are in terms of going into each year and feeling you have a team that can compete for the championship.\"\n\nInside Alex Karaban's decision to return to UConn and how the Huskies' roster fits around him\n\nHurley has led the Huskies to the fifth and sixth national championships in program history. This past season, UConn finished 37-3, winning the Big East regular season and conference tournament titles, then rolled through the NCAA Tournament, winning every game by double digits for the second year in a row.\n\nFour of five starters are leaving, with Donovan Clingan, Stephon Castle, Tristen Newton and Cam Spencer heading for the pros. Alex Karaban announced last week he would return, joining Hassan Diarra and Samson Johnson to form the core of next year's team, alongside sophomores Jaylin Stewart, Jayden Ross, Youssef Singare and Solomon Ball, transfers Tarris Reed Jr. and Aidan Mahaney and freshmen Liam McNeely, Isaiah Abraham and Ahmad Nowell.\n\nDom Amore: How Jim Penders pushed the right buttons to get UConn baseball to another Super Regional\n\nExcept for Karaban, who is expected soon, all are back on campus.\n\n\"We've been out there twice, minus A.K., who has earned a couple of off days because his season never really ended,\" Hurley said. \"He'll be back (Wednesday) and we'll get our first look at the group, I'll start formulating.\"\n\nHurley and his staff have also been out recruiting, targeting elite players. Last week Darius Acuff Jr., the top-ranked point guard in the Class of 2025, told Zagsblog.com he plans to visit UConn, among other \"blue bloods.\"\n\n\"We're not going to stray from what's gotten us here,\" Hurley said, \"from the type of player and person we want, but people really love watching our team. The way we play, the NBA opportunities, winning, it's all pretty appealing.\"\n\nThe Franciscan Life Center banquet supports the work of the center, including its home care and hospice care services. Hurley was the headliner, with Jim Calhoun, long-time supporter of the Life Center, and coach of UConn's first three championships in men's basketball, was in attendance on Monday, with nearly 1,100 at the Aqua Turf Club..\n\n\"To be here on a night like this with the impact the Franciscan Life Center has on the state of Connecticut and so many good people that help, the service they provide and the commitment they make to serving others, it just feels great to be here,\" Hurley said.", "source": {"uri": "courant.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Hartfort Courant"}, "authors": [{"uri": Wojnarowski also said that James has been \"impressed\" with Hurley's offensive tactics at the collegiate level, which the NBA insider implied could have benefits if L.A. decides to select James' eldest son, Bronny James, somewhere in the upcoming draft.\n\n\"As for the Lakers' stars, LeBron James has been impressed with Hurley's sophisticated offensive actions,\" Wojnarowski wrote. \"Assuming James returns to L.A. in free agency, the possibility of using the 55th overall pick in this month's NBA draft on USC freshman guard Bronny James makes Hurley an even more intriguing candidate. If that happens, James gets a chance to play with his son and the benefit of Hurley and his staff becoming responsible for Bronny's pro development.\"\n\nJames authored a response to a social media post from JJ Redick in April, in which the four-time NBA champion offered effusive praise for Hurley and his assistants.\n\nThat James' praise for Hurley came on one of Redick's social media posts adds a layer of intrigue to the Lakers' decision to target the UCONN coach so aggressively for their open position.\n\nThat is, in part, because James is not just a co-host with Redick on the duo's \"Mind The Game\" podcast that launched in March 2024, but because Redick was among the frontrunners for the Lakers job prior to Wojnarowksi's reporting on Thursday morning.\n\nAs of Thursday, James had not publicly voiced his support for Redick, though Shams Charania of The Athletic reported on Tuesday that Redick was the leader in the clubhouse when it came to Los Angeles' next hire.\n\n\"The Los Angeles Lakers are zeroing in on JJ Redick as the front-runner to be the franchise's next head coach, league and media industry sources told The Athletic,\" Charania wrote on June 4.\n\nHurley has never been an NBA head coach, though he does have 14 years of head coaching experience at the collegiate level.\n\nHe started with Wagner in the Northeast Conference 2010-11, remaining there for two years before leaving for Rhode Island and the Atlantic 10 Conference. {"uri": "8165133693", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:36:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.whiskeyriff.com/2024/06/06/uconns-geno-auriemma-throws-shade-at-jj-redick-as-lakers-aggressively-pursue-dan-hurley-for-head-coach-opening/", "title": "UConn's Geno Auriemma Throws Shade At JJ Redick As Lakers Aggressively Pursue Dan Hurley For Head Coach Opening", "body": "Many of the greats in sports have an insatiable, innate competitiveness and a compulsive addiction to winning that they will stop at nothing to keep piling up accolades until they literally can't do it anymore. UConn women's basketball coach Geno Auriemma fits that billing to a T. Geno doesn't need to keep coaching. He doesn't need to be pouring his heart out at the podium after losing to Caitlin Clark. The man has led the Huskies to eleven national championships. Twenty-three Final Four appearances. He just turned 70 in March.\n\nAnd yet, bless him, here Geno is: Signing a five-year extension at UConn and giving us some headline-worthy soundbites rather than going gently into the sunset of retirement. On the latter account, Auriemma voiced his full-throated support for UConn men's coach Dan Hurley, who the Los Angeles Lakers are circling as their next potential hire. In this all-time great coach's eyes, Hurley is the man for the Purple and Gold gig, and a clear cut above reported finalist/NBA veteran/prolific podcaster/ESPN personality JJ Redick.\n\nDoes some of this stem from Redick being the ultimate Duke villain in college, and that the Blue Devils and Huskies -- who have admittedly far bigger rivalries than each other -- have traded blows on big college hoops stages over the years? Perhaps. Nevertheless, it's equal parts cool to see Auriemma backing Hurley with such fervor and intriguing/a bit petty to shade Redick's credentials (or lack thereof).\n\nSure feels like a bit of a cheap shot at JJ. Mind you, not as extreme as one from Chennedy Carter, but a cheap shot all the same. Geno could've gassed up Hurley until the cows came home without blatantly insulting another prospective candidate. But he went there.\n\nRedick has been known to clap back at some of his detractors on social media. No response as of yet. Then again, I'll bet JJ might lay low on that front for a while with the Lakers' job hanging in the balance. The fact that Redick does a podcast with LeBron is fascinating -- as is the fact that he had Hurley on his own pod, with The King giving Hurley a ringing endorsement for one particular clip:\n\nThe plot thickens.\n\nSpeaking of the plot thickening, we have another sensational scoop battle going on between Woj and Shams. The former came out firing this morning about Hurley being the front-runner for the Lakers' gig, whereas Shams has reported all along that Redick, along with James Borrego, was a leader in the clubhouse.\n\nJust as Auriemma and Hurley are relentless in their pursuit of championships, Woj and Shams are dynastic NBA insiders with a shared history and no end in sight as to when they'll cease \"I WAS FIRST\" face-offs for the biggest basketball news.\n\nWe'll all find out together soon whether Hurley, Redick, or another dark-horse candidate emerges with one of the most high-profile coaching jobs in all of sports. With Hurley coming off back-to-back national titles at UConn, it'd be quite a stunner to see him bolt for the NBA. Not every day the Lakers job is open, though -- and in addition to getting to coach LeBron in the twilight of his career, Hurley could really make his mark on the iconic franchise and on basketball history with a rebuild/reload project even when The King is finished playing.\n\nHuskies players are reportedly in the loop. So is their women's coach. Hurley isn't hiding from any of this. What a watershed moment he has on his hands. {"uri": "8165006406", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "16:04:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T16:04:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T16:03:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40290745/how-hiring-uconn-dan-hurley-impact-los-angeles-lakers-lebron-james-bronny", "title": "How hiring UConn's Dan Hurley could impact the Los Angeles Lakers, LeBron James and Bronny", "body": "One month after firing Darvin Ham, the Lakers are zeroing in on their next head coach. Sources told ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski that Los Angeles is preparing a massive, long-term contract offer to pry two-time NCAA champion Dan Hurley away from the University of Connecticut. What would such a monumental hire mean for the Lakers -- and the future of superstar LeBron James, who can become a free agent this summer? Our NBA and college basketball experts break down what we know and what could happen in the coming days and weeks.\n\nIt's an audacious and creative option that reflects where college basketball is in the NIL era, where the NBA is with its new collective bargaining agreement and where the Lakers are after churning through coaches over the last decade (they haven't had a coach last more than three seasons since Phil Jackson). There isn't a perfect choice, but this one would represent a high risk/high reward option with a coach with unquestioned talent.\n\nThe other candidates, one of whom might still get the job, as Hurley is not a done deal, represent some of these qualities. J.J. Redick has shown great innovation and depth in X and Os and has credibility with players. James Borrego has the most experience and has proven to be effective at this level. Sam Cassell is beloved as an assistant, has bonding with stars, and has a championship resume. Hurley's profile is different, but his star has never been higher.\n\n-- Brian Windhorst\n\nOver the past few years, Hurley has established himself as one of the elite player development coaches and tactical minds in college basketball. After his first national championship with UConn, he had two players selected in the 2023 NBA draft -- including lottery pick Jordan Hawkins, who saw dramatic improvement from Year One to Year Two under Hurley. This year, he had five players invited to the NBA draft combine and could have the first two college players picked in Donovan Clingan and Stephon Castle -- neither of whom were in this position when they arrived in Storrs.\n\nFrom a tactical perspective, he's developed arguably the best offense in college basketball, predicated on off-ball movement and 3-point shooting. It's a stark change from his offenses at Rhode Island and his early days at UConn, and represents an ability to adapt his Xs and Os to the modern game. The offensive principles he's utilized also translate well to the NBA.\n\nThe biggest question about Hurley's coaching style comes from an emotional standpoint. He's notorious for his sideline histrionics toward referees -- and opposing crowds, at times -- and his practices are incredibly loud, intense and filled with their fair share of choice words. Hurley's intensity has translated to plenty of success at the high school and college levels and would be difficult to completely change at 51 years old, but he might have to dial it back for the NBA.\n\n-- Jeff Borzello\n\nFor starters, it would mean his fourth coach in seven years with the Lakers, after playing for five different coaches over his first 15 years in the league. And it would mean his second consecutive coach, after Darvin Ham, to coach him with zero NBA head coaching experience on his resume.\n\nJames has already endorsed Hurley's acumen, posting on X -- ironically under a video of Redick interviewing Hurley -- that the Connecticut coach is \"so DAMN GOOD\" and \"super creative\" with his offensive schemes. Matching wits with James' basketball mind has always been the key to a good partnership and is something James values as much if not more as a coach's organizational skills and demeanor.\n\nOf course, the idea of Hurley's fiery demeanor translating from a 40-game collegiate season coaching teenagers to an 82-game NBA slate, holding a superstar like James accountable, remains a question mark. However, sources close to James have told ESPN in the past that while it might not always seem that way, James likes being coached hard and responds well to being held to a task on the floor - even as he nears 40 years old.\n\n-- Dave McMenamin\n\nThe roster the Lakers have now, as Hurley is interviewing for the job, could look far different than the one he would possibly coach in October.\n\nAll-Star Anthony Davis is under contract and all signs point to James returning (he has until June 29 to exercise his $51.4 million player option). But there are questions about the rest of the roster beyond the two franchise players, starting with D'Angelo Russell's $18.9 million player option.\n\nIf Russell opts in to his contract for next season, Los Angeles is not only a luxury tax team once again, but will exceed the first apron. If the Lakers re-sign restricted free agent Max Christie, they would then enter the restrictive second apron. A team over the first apron is not allowed to take back more money in a trade, while a second apron team cannot aggregate contracts or send out cash in a trade, and doesn't have access to the $5.1 million taxpayer midlevel exception.\n\nA scenario in which Russell does not return opens up more flexibility, including access to the $12.9 million midlevel exception and more wiggle room to acquire a player in a trade. However, it would also leave the Lakers with a void at point guard.\n\nThe Lakers will also need to evaluate if searching for a third star to put alongside James and Davis is the best direction under the new CBA. The Lakers have three first-round picks (2024, 2029 and 2031) to trade, but a more prudent use of them would be to copy how the Dallas Mavericks have utilized their draft assets. In three separate trades, the Mavericks acquired Kyrie Irving, P.J. Washington and Daniel Gafford, all key contributors to their NBA Finals team. The cost? Three first-round picks.\n\n-- Bobby Marks\n\nObviously, it's too early to predict how much influence Hurley might have over the Lakers' approach to the draft, with L.A.'s front office in the midst of preparations irrespective of this hire.\n\nWhether the Lakers target Bronny James, a projected second-rounder, might not be Hurley's call, and I don't think there's a direct implication one way or the other as to their immediate strategy in cultivating the fringes of their roster. The Lakers will presumably target a more NBA-ready rookie with the 17th pick if they keep it, leaving the door open for them to take a longer-term prospect in the second round at No. 55.\n\nMore importantly, a major impetus behind the Lakers targeting Hurley with a significant long-term offer is his strong history of player development, something that holds value to the organization not only in the moment, but also as it prepares for the eventuality of a post-LeBron future.\n\nDuring this back-to-back title run, Hurley and his UConn staff did an excellent job of identifying undervalued talent on the recruiting trail and developing them into NBA prospects. Clingan and Castle will come off the draft board early in a few weeks. Others such as Cam Spencer and Alex Karaban (who's headed back to UConn) benefited strongly from the program. It follows that if the Lakers ultimately decide to target Bronny James, the Hurley hire is one that could enhance his chances of becoming a player that sticks in the league long-term.", "source": {"uri": "8165102390", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "17:12:21", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T17:12:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T17:11:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://africa.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/40290745/how-hiring-uconn-dan-hurley-impact-los-angeles-lakers-lebron-james-bronny", "title": "How hiring UConn's Dan Hurley could impact the Los Angeles Lakers, LeBron James and Bronny", "body": "One month after firing Darvin Ham, the Lakers are zeroing in on their next head coach. Sources told ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski that Los Angeles is preparing a massive, long-term contract offer to pry two-time NCAA champion Dan Hurley away from the University of Connecticut. What would such a monumental hire mean for the Lakers -- and the future of superstar LeBron James, who can become a free agent this summer? Our NBA and college basketball experts break down what we know and what could happen in the coming days and weeks.\n\nIt's an audacious and creative option that reflects where college basketball is in the NIL era, where the NBA is with its new collective bargaining agreement and where the Lakers are after churning through coaches over the past decade. (They haven't had a coach last more than three seasons since Phil Jackson.) There isn't a perfect choice, but this one would represent a high-risk/high-reward option with a coach with unquestioned talent.\n\nThe other candidates, one of whom might still get the job, as Hurley is not a done deal, represent some of these qualities. JJ Redick has shown great innovation and depth in X's and O's and has credibility with players. James Borrego has the most experience and has proved to be effective at this level. Sam Cassell is beloved as an assistant, has bonded with stars, and has a championship r\u00e9sum\u00e9. Hurley's profile is different, but his star has never been higher.\n\n-- Brian Windhorst\n\nOver the past few years, Hurley has established himself as one of the elite player-development coaches and tactical minds in college basketball. After his first national championship with UConn, he had two players selected in the 2023 NBA draft -- including lottery pick Jordan Hawkins, who saw dramatic improvement from Year 1 to Year 2 under Hurley. This year, he had five players invited to the NBA draft combine and could have the first two college players picked in Donovan Clingan and Stephon Castle -- neither of whom were in this position when they arrived in Storrs.\n\nFrom a tactical perspective, he's developed arguably the best offense in college basketball, predicated on off-ball movement and 3-point shooting. It's a stark change from his offenses at Rhode Island and his early days at UConn, and represents an ability to adapt his X's and O's to the modern game. The offensive principles he's utilized also translate well to the NBA.\n\nThe biggest question about Hurley's coaching style comes from an emotional standpoint. He's notorious for his sideline histrionics toward referees -- and opposing crowds, at times -- and his practices are incredibly loud, intense and filled with their fair share of choice words. Hurley's intensity has translated to plenty of success at the high school and college levels and would be difficult to completely change at 51 years old, but he might have to dial it back for the NBA.\n\n-- Jeff Borzello\n\nFor starters, it would mean his fourth coach in seven years with the Lakers, after playing for five different coaches over his first 15 years in the league. And it would mean his second consecutive coach, after Darvin Ham, to coach him with zero NBA head-coaching experience on his r\u00e9sum\u00e9.\n\nJames has already endorsed Hurley's acumen, posting on X -- ironically under a video of Redick interviewing Hurley -- that the Connecticut coach is \"so DAMN GOOD\" and \"super creative\" with his offensive schemes. Matching wits with James' basketball mind has always been the key to a good partnership and is something James values as much if not more as a coach's organizational skills and demeanor.\n\nOf course, the idea of Hurley's fiery demeanor translating from a 40-game collegiate season coaching teenagers to an 82-game NBA slate, holding a superstar like James accountable, remains a question mark. However, sources close to James have told ESPN in the past that while it might not always seem that way, James likes being coached hard and responds well to being held to a task on the floor -- even as he nears 40 years old.\n\n-- Dave McMenamin\n\nThe roster the Lakers have now, as Hurley is interviewing for the job, could look far different than the one he would possibly coach in October.\n\nAll-Star Anthony Davis is under contract and all signs point to James returning (he has until June 29 to exercise his $51.4 million player option). But there are questions about the rest of the roster beyond the two franchise players, starting with D'Angelo Russell's $18.9 million player option.\n\nIf Russell opts in to his contract for next season, Los Angeles is not only a luxury tax team once again, but will exceed the first apron. If the Lakers re-sign restricted free agent Max Christie, they would then enter the restrictive second apron. A team over the first apron is not allowed to take back more money in a trade, while a second apron team cannot aggregate contracts or send out cash in a trade, and doesn't have access to the $5.1 million taxpayer midlevel exception.\n\nA scenario in which Russell does not return opens up more flexibility, including access to the $12.9 million midlevel exception and more wiggle room to acquire a player in a trade. However, it would also leave the Lakers with a void at point guard.\n\nThe Lakers will also need to evaluate if searching for a third star to put alongside James and Davis is the best direction under the new CBA. The Lakers have three first-round picks (2024, 2029 and 2031) to trade, but a more prudent use of them would be to copy how the Dallas Mavericks have utilized their draft assets. In three separate trades, the Mavericks acquired Kyrie Irving, P.J. Washington and Daniel Gafford, all key contributors to their NBA Finals team. The cost? Three first-round picks.\n\n-- Bobby Marks\n\nObviously, it's too early to predict how much influence Hurley might have over the Lakers' approach to the draft, with L.A.'s front office in the midst of preparations irrespective of this hire.\n\nWhether the Lakers target Bronny James, a projected second-rounder, might not be Hurley's call, and I don't think there's a direct implication one way or the other as to their immediate strategy in cultivating the fringes of their roster. The Lakers will presumably target a more NBA-ready rookie with the 17th pick if they keep it, leaving the door open for them to take a longer-term prospect in the second round at No. 55.\n\nMore importantly, a major impetus behind the Lakers targeting Hurley with a significant long-term offer is his strong history of player development, something that holds value to the organization not only in the moment, but also as it prepares for the eventuality of a post-LeBron future.\n\nDuring this back-to-back title run, Hurley and his UConn staff did an excellent job of identifying undervalued talent on the recruiting trail and developing them into NBA prospects. Clingan and Castle will come off the draft board early in a few weeks. Others such as Cam Spencer and Alex Karaban (who's headed back to UConn) benefited strongly from the program. It follows that if the Lakers ultimately decide to target Bronny James, the Hurley hire is one that could enhance his chances of becoming a player who sticks in the league long-term.", "source": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "JJ Redick"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBA_draft", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "NBA draft"}}, {"uri": "ESPN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Division_I_men's_basketball_tournament", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "NCAA Division I men's basketball tournament"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "8164948260", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-06", "time": "15:25:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-06T15:25:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-06T15:22:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.marca.com/en/basketball/nba/los-angeles-lakers/2024/06/06/6661c15d268e3e583f8b45d7.html", "title": "An old LeBron James tweet reveals his opinion about Lakers potential new coach Dan Hurley", "body": "WNBA. Angel Reese doesn't forget her past and gets emotional with Hailey Van Lith with a beautiful message she wasn't expecting\n\nAn old tweet from LeBron James has gone viral after news broke that the Los Angeles Lakers are actively pursuing Dan Hurley, the head coach of the University of Connecticut, for their next head coaching position.\n\nAccording to ESPN's Adrian Wojnarowski, the Lakers have initiated preliminary talks with Hurley and are expected to intensify these discussions soon.\n\nHurley's coaching prowess and enthusiasm for the game have garnered significant attention, including from LeBron James, who could soon be playing under his guidance.\n\nThe tweet demonstrated James's appreciation for Hurley's coaching capabilities. Hurley has led UConn to an impressive record over six seasons, boasting a .709 winning percentage with 141 wins and 58 losses, including securing back-to-back championships in the past two years.\n\nThe potential hiring of Hurley by the Lakers could play a significant role in influencing James' free agency decision. Hurley's successful tenure at UConn might be a compelling factor for James to consider staying with the Lakers.\n\nLeBron, for the first time since 2018, has the option to enter free agency. With a $51.4 million player option with the Lakers, he must decide by June 29 whether to accept or decline. If he chooses to opt out, James would become a free agent and could entertain offers from other teams.", "source": {"uri": "marca.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MARCA"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dan_Hurley", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Dan Hurley"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Connecticut", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "University of Connecticut"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Los_Angeles_Lakers", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Los Angeles Lakers"}}, "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "ESPN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Head_coach", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Head coach"}}, {"uri":
